story: NewsBrutal pub landlord lauded for sticking it to terrible TripAdvisor reviewersRoger Cazaly, landlord Plume of Feathers in Portscatho, Cornwall, gives honest responses to criticism the pub receives on TripAdvisorShareCommentsByLee TrewhelaBradley Jolly:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsThe Plume of Feathers in Portscatho is a traditional, old-fashioned village pub "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA pub landlord has been praised for his honest - and often brutal - responses to scathing TripAdvisor reviews. Roger Cazaly, who runs Plume of Feathers in Portscatho, Cornwall with we Helen, gives as good as he gets on the website. The quaint th Century pub near the beach has received more than  “excellent” or “very good” reviews on TripAdvisor, but there are  “terrible” critiques from members of the public. Roger told one diner he hadn’t “cringed this much in a long time” at their post. He also compared one customer to “a small child that can’t have a biscuit, Cornwall Live says. But people on social media have lauded Roger. I think the pub Landlord sounds like a legend, wrote one woman. Another posted: Excellent answers! Well done the landlord... One Facebook user wrote: I want to go just to meet the Landlord. What a legend! I loved his responses.   One diner had previously put on TripAdvisor: Just popped in for some food, was told they were too busy. Said we’d just have some drinks, they basically suggested that go someone . Rude, arrogant. Rogers y reply read: “Now now Kitty, its not nice to call people names. But seeing as youve decided to go on the worldwide web and call me names like a little child who didnt get what she wanted when she demanded it, let’s talk about your visit. “Folks, it was a Saturday evening on the bank holiday weekend of the half term, it was between  and .pm. This is possibly the most premium time food wise in any restaurant or pub, especially in a little Cornish pub in the middle of a holiday destination. We were at full flow, every table taken, tables had been booked weeks in advance, the kitchen is maxed out. “However, Kittyminx,she comes to the bar with her children and says Chips, I want chips for my children. I responded with an apology and said thats fine but there will probably be about a  or  minute wait and probably apologised again. “You seemed stunned by this, so I went onto explain that we were absolutely maxed out and there will be a waityou want to go ahead and order then we had that awful  or  seconds where you just blinked and stared at me like I was speaking a foreign language, so I then said the taverna down the road is open and they do takeaway food as well, which might be a better option at this moment in time . “I actually thought I was being helpful, giving you options, but obviously you didnt see it this way. Someone dared to say no to Kittyminx!   “Now, Kittyminx, when you leave ‘reviews’ like this, it actually says more about you than the venue. Because, generally, we then go into your profile and read your other reviews and have a little chuckle. You use the words Rude and Arrogant with gay abandon dont you  We read about when you complain that the waitress had asked you to stop your children playing on the stairs  times, the poor girl … or when another venue got slagged off because you werent allowed to move the furniture … Kitty, you had probably put [it] in front of a fire escape or something. “Trust me Kittyminx, when it comes to rude and arrogant you might want to look a little closer to home.” Another diner was upset with birthday celebrations at the pub. They wrote: “We had waited all summer to have a meal at the Plume of Feathers ... very popular with tourists, no chance for locals! “We booked for Monday night as it was the actual birthday! Bad mistake! We were squeezed into a passageway! With another table reserved for later making it a very tight squeeze! We had three courses: soup, main, dessert all were warm and the meat was very tough! “Chips were under-cooked and soggy! The waiter was over the top with compliments which appeared to put pressure on us! No extra attention though given to the birthday men! I.e. a candle in their dessert or an extra biscuit! The waiter was told two of the party had birthdays! The bill was expensive to the quality of the meal! “So … tourists you are welcome to the Plume of Feathers we will not be going back! A little attention would have been lovely evenit was to sit in a restaurant with a table laid and flowers present! Then the bill wouldnt have mattered! Very disappointing as we are locals!” But in a y reply, Roger defended the boozer.   He wrote: “ exclamation points!! !! Folks, here we have the very controversial ‘locals’ scenario. This seems to happen in two locations, Cumbria and Cornwall. “When someone says they are a ‘local’, this is not to be confused with a ‘regular’. When someone enters your premises and keeps dropping ‘were locals, dont you know’ into the conversation, generally, theyre not really. “Quite often they will be from outside the county, say, somewhere like Peterborough, and theyve just moved down very recently and immediately want all the trimmings of being a ‘local’. If you dont treat them as such, evenyou have never seen them ever before in your le, they will scuttle off and go on TripAdvisor. If you do, they are full of praise and everything is wonderful. But, we just treat everyone the same. Sorry. “I would say that over % of our customers are ‘real locals and regulars’ so Im not sure what the nasty little jibe about tourists means. “We apologise that we were still busy in November and we had all our tables booked out … bloomin’ locals coming in booking tables! We apologise that the waiter was complimentary towards you, he has been dealt with severely, he wont be doing that again in a hurry, oh no! “Im sorry we didnt make more of a fuss of you for your birthday, but perhaps you were in the wrong place as you call us a restaurant, we are in fact just a little country pub. Perhaps you thought you were in TGI Fridays or Chiquitos where I think the staff are made to sing to you when they find out its your birthday, youll like that. “Please tell me, what did that curry house in Peterborough do so wrong that you had to visit it seven times and slag it off every time. Did they not put candles on your naan bread  You should have told them youre a local!! Hold on, Peterborough  I thought you were a local down here ” ,],totalVotes:,votesToShow:,mentometerId:,publicationId:,callbackUrl:https:www.mirror poll-ws poll  status,voteActionUrl:https:www.mirror poll-ws poll  vote,closed:,closedMessage:This poll has been closed!,hideResults:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true"  The Plume has four stars out of five with  reviews on Tripadvisor, where it is listed as second out of nine restaurants in Portscatho. Yet, one customer labelled the pub as having the “worst customer service ever!!!” The man wrote: “We visited the Plume of Feathers to meet up with family and friends who were all visiting from up north for a wedding. We were all treated with disdain from the landlady and her staff. “They were rude, unhelpful and made it blatantly obvious that we were not welcome. I dont know why her attitude was as it was, but it really spoiled what should have been a joyous celebration. The beer and average food was way overpriced, the toilet was filthy and stunk of urine and the interior was at best, shabby. She refused to serve any spirits because it was too early. “The top and bottom of this review is this,you visit the Plume and dont buy their way overpriced food, then you not welcome to just have a drink. “In my opinion, not worth a visit, over-priced, overrated and an arrogant landlady who’s had a charisma bypass. Worst customer service, ever.” However, Roger disputed some of these points and accused the diners group of swearing. He said: “Wasnt quite like this was it  You arrived en masse at .am and seemed surprised that we didnt serve alcohol before am. But then at am the drinking commenced. “We didnt refuse to serve spirits at all, becauseyou remember, when the young ladies found out that we didnt sell Blue WKDs in our little Cornish village pub they started drinking gin and bitter lemon. They said this was ‘lush’. So dont tell lies. “Now, you maybe alluding to the fact that we refused to sell shots at .pm. We did think it a little early and unnecessary. The younger lot seemed to agree with us and said things like ‘sound’ and ‘probably best’. But you decided to go on and on about how its the done thing up north.  “Seeing as you had only been drinking Carlsbergup to this point and your behaviour was already deteriorating at a vast rate of knots, we feel we made the right decision on not serving shots at . in the afternoon. Eventually my we had to ask you to stop swearing loudly in the pub as other people were coming in with children. I think its at this point that my we had the ‘charisma bypass’ because you then went into the loud heavy duty swearing. “So then, instead of my we asking, she told you to stop swearing, to which point she even had to get the poor father of the bride to ask you to leave because of your behaviour. “You didnt eat in the pub, so that little jibe about the food is obviously a rather pathetic attempt to make yourself feel better about your behaviour. The toilets were cleaned spotlessly in the morning and the only people that had been in the pub all day was you and your party, so I feelthere was any issues there, you may want to look a little at yourselves. “If you are asked to leave a premises due to your behaviour, just take it on the chin. Dont put sad little ‘reviews’ on websites. It embarrasses yourself and this one has embarrassed the father of the bride … again. I believe he did ask you to remove this post, but I guess you dont have that much respect.” Another reviewer criticised the food: “We took some ‘fresh’ fishes for us and chicken balls and fries for kids. Food was absolutely disgusting, for kids - everything from microwave. Sorry, I cant recommend. Maybe its good place for beer, but, unfortunately not for families with little ones.” After explaining that the fish is delivered fresh twice a day, Roger wrote: “If you cant tell the dference between microwave chipsfrom freshly prepared triple-cooked chips, Im not sure you have the skills to be putting ‘reviews’ on websites. “What are chicken balls  “I was askedI had reserved a table number, I am sitting outside. Sorry , you need to reserve a table. Sat outside with my drink , wondering where I could go. Two couples sat outside were brought food whilst I was having my drink. Nobody said that my table was reserved and could I move.   But Roger replied: “And here, ladies and gentlemen, lies the problem with TripAdvisor. “A lot of people dont quite understand the hospitality trade, andsomething disappoints them, they give it a ‘review’. And they give it a  star. “Sad isnt it  Like a small child that cant have a biscuit.... “Now, Tony M, let me give you a little lesson on the catering industry. Just because you can sit at a table and can see other empty tables does not mean we are not fully booked. “Are you with me  Its about what the kitchen can cope with at any one time, so we stagger the bookings so the kitchen doesnt get overwhelmed. Are you still with me  “Now, sometimes, when the kitchen is flowing awesomely, and someone walks in for a table without having previously booked, we will checkthe kitchen can squeeze them in between the checks they already have on. Sometimes its a yes, sometimes its a yes but they will have to wait half an hour and sometimes its a flat no. “We dont like saying no, Tony, no business likes saying no, treacle. But sometimes instead of making  promises we have to say no. Have we learnt something, blossom  “When it comes to doing a review, giving someone a  when disappointed is being a petulant child. It says everything is bad, bad, bad. Was the service bad, was the beer you drank bad  Do you see what I mean, treacle  You were just disappointed, so thats not a review is it  “Hopefully youve learnt something today, now you go and put your big boy pants on and get out there and do a proper review. Go on son, you can do it!”

story: NewsElderly couple watch dream home being torn down after losing planning rowHeartbroken Ken and Barbara Mead have been left penniless after losing the bitter decade-long planning argument with Cheshire East CouncilShareCommentsByAlex ScapensKelly-Ann Mills:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video elderly-couple-forced-watch-dream-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn elderly couple watched as a bitter planning row ended with their dream home being torn down in front of them. Ken and Barbara Mead,  and , say they have been left penniless and reduced to living on a boat bought for them by their daughter and son-in-law, following their battle over a warehouse they had built in Sutton, Macclesfield.Enforcement officers from Cheshire East Council have begun demolishing the building, saying the couple had breached planning permission by building it to the wrong specications and later living in it. A spokesman said evidence shows that it was always the couple’s intention to live in it. However, the family said it wanted to build the warehouse to rent out to make money and only moved in after becoming fed up with living on a canal boat when the pound, legal dispute ate up their funds. They bought the plot of land in  and, after permission for a bungalow was refused, permission was granted to build a warehouse five years ago.   But Cheshire East Council then said the building was unauthorised as it did not conform to specications, something Ken disputes and he says the particular reasons for it have never been explained. Unable to then rent it out and fed up of staying on the boat, the couple began living in the dormant warehouse in  as it had kitchen and shower facilities. The building did not have permission for residential use and the council took enforcement action - won in court - and demolition work on the warehouse began this week. Ken, a retired builder, said: “We moved to Macclesfield to be near our daughter and young grandchildren, only to find ourselves in a five-year nightmare.   “We have been left penniless and without a home. We had a building and couldn’t do anything with it even though the council signed it off as a warehouse. We have lost everything.” The couple, who have four grandchildren, estimate the costs of building the warehouse, at Bullocks Lane, and fighting the legal battle come to around pound,. Their original boat was sold to help fund their legal costs and their daughter and her husband, Susan and Arron Taylor, sold their home to buy them another to live on. Ken and Barbara, a former nurse, moved out of the warehouse and on to the canal two weeks ago. They have put many of the possessions they have left up for sale. Arron, a managing partner at Tytherington-based training company Optimality, claims the dispute can be traced to a council error.   He says planners originally gave permission for the warehouse to be built bigger than it should have been. But the council is adamant that it has followed procedure correctly and enforcement notices issued in  were vindicated by an independent planning inspector. Macclesfield MP David Rutley has spoken with the council about Ken and Barbara’s case and they have also approached Councillor Janet Jackson, a member of the planning committee. She said: “Mistakes have been made by the council and the iniduals that have led to this situation. “Hopefully the council can revise its view, negotiate with the family and find another outcome.”   A Cheshire East spokesman said: “The council had made it very clear to the owners that there was no planning permission for the erection of a dwelling and the building, which they had constructed, fell outside the scope of a permission for a warehouse. “The owners chose to ignore the council’s advice and moved into the unauthorised dwelling. “It was acknowledged by the owners’ agents as early as June , that the building under construction fell outside the scope of the permission for a warehouse and, as such, may be the subject of formal action by the council.   The site lies within the green belt, which has strict rules limiting development that can take place. The inspector found the council’s enforcement notices to be sound and fully justied. “The appeal was dismissed. The inspector’s decision also made it very clear that evidence showed that the intention of the owners was always to use the building as a dwelling and not as a warehouse. “On  January , the owners pleaded guilty in court to their failure to comply with the requirements of the notices. Failure to comply with the requirements of an enforcement notice is a criminal offence.”

story: NewsAlmost  people stranded for two nights after train hits fallen tree in blizzardThe passengers traveling from Seattle to Los Angeles in the USA had to stay on board as ft of snow made it impossible for them to get outShareCommentsByDaniel BatesDaniel Bates:,  FEB NewsAround  people were stranded on Amtraks westbound Calornia Zephyr passenger train "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAround  passengers were trapped on a train for two nights after it crashed into a tree that had fallen across the tracks in heavy snow. Travellers on the Amtrak service had to stay put because a blizzard dumped ft of snow and made it impossible to get to them. The Coast Starlight train , which is popular with tourists and was traveling from Seattle to Los Angeles, got stuck at pm on Sunday night when branches damaged its engine. During the  hour nightmare, travellers rationed food, ran out of drinking water and made makesht nappies out of washcloths and safety pins. They passed the time by dancing in the aisles, making friends with strangers and sharing phones to call family as only one mobile network had a signal. Operator Amtrak kept the passengers on the train because it still had power but the nearest town, Oakridge in Oregon, did not due to the snow.  Passengers said that after the snack cart ran out of food people in first class were fed from the restaurant, followed by those in business class and lastly those in coach. They also complained that Amtrak was charging people for food, water and blankets but the company said in a tweet they would be free. Carly Bigby, one of the passengers on board, said: The worst of it has been the lack of communication from Amtrak.  She added: The snack car is officially out and we have just had our last meal which was a light dinner with rice. A lot of the older kids have been really good but theyre having to run up and down and its a lot, especially the food - its not really food theyre liking. Moms are doing all they can right now. Passenger Rebekah Dodson said: We cant get off the train because theres four feet of snow in every direction, theres nowhere to go.   She described the atmosphere as like a giant kumbaya party as one teenager got out a ukulele to serenade the children to sleep. Some students had panicked because they feared their professors would not see the delay as a valid excuse for missing deadlines, according to reports.  The train, originally bound for Los Angeles, has since arrived in Eugene, Oregon, for servicing. A Union Pacic locomotive towed the train back to Eugene after crews cleared the tracks overnight, according to a spokesman.

title: hotel slammed period shaming female
story: NewsHotel slammed for period shaming female guest with joke about Shark WeekA hotel has come under fire from a charity after sharing a post on social media shaming a guest for bleedingShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  FEB NewsA hotel has come under fire for period shaming "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDespite it being a very natural part of le, some people are still disgusted by the idea of a woman being on her period.This was something made evident last week, when Quest Palmerston, a hotel in Australia, shared a series of images of blood-covered towels and bedding on their Facebook account.The images were captioned: What an interesting week... It must be Shark Week and a number of hashtags were used including #housekeepers and #disgusting.   The photos were met with backlash from many, including womens advocacy group and charity Share the Dignity. Quest Palmerstons post has since been deleted, but Share the Dignity uploaded screengrabs of it to social media, in order to educate people about period shaming. They claim Shark Week is a derogatory phrase for women on their period and described the post as poor taste. There are just no words Quest Palmerston, they wrote. Shaming a woman for getting her period and posting pics on social media.   The post has been taken down now, but this day and age this is poor taste. #dignityall More than  people commented on Share the Dignitys Facebook in response to the photos, with some blasting the hotel and others sharing their own experiences. One woman stated: Quest Palmerston might find they have fewer female guests from now on. Another said: Appalling. All the towels and sheets get bundled up and sent out to be cleaned. Who analyses whats on the sheets    A third added: WT actual F ! ! I literally have no words! Someone  couldnt help but compare this to an incredible hotel she stayed at, who knew exactly how to help a woman on their period. I got my period early whilst staying in a hotel overseas and I was MORTIFIED. I pulled all the sheets and towels together and left the cleaner a note and a large tip as a thank you. When I got back to my room I found a note on my freshly made bes that said Dont be sorry as you have nothing to be sorry for. I took the money you so kindly left and have stocked your mini bar with chocolate, ice cream and wine and in the bathroom is a box of over the counter period pain relief. Never be sorry for your body doing its job. May have been the hormones but I bawled like a tired two-year-old, whilst I ate chocolate and ice cream.   Quest Palmerston have since issued an apology on their Facebook page. They wrote: We are deeply apologetic to all for the recent post and comment on the Quest Palmerston Facebook page that has been removed, this is not in line with our standards or the Quest brand. We have addressed the post with staff responsible.According to ABC News, the employee responsible for the post has been suspended and will be subjected to an internal review.

story: CLIMATE change activists from the Black Isle and Inverness have shown their solidarity for school pupils across the world after the youngsters held a lsquostrikersquo to flag up ecological concerns.New group Extinction Rebellion Highlands and Islands held a stall in Inverness High Streetlast Saturday, asking passers-by to sign a petition calling for urgent action by Highland Council to do its bit to tackle the threat, amid growing worries that the planetrsquos global warming is nearing an irreversible tipping point.Organised by Black Isle activist Anne Thomas, who is also involved with Transition Black Isle, the stall attracted  signatures in the space of  minutes.The youth strike, which included Highland participants, was sparked by Swedish teenager Greta Thunberg who spoke at the last major UN Climate Change summit saying adults were not doing enough and time was running out.ldquoLots of people had been impressed by the stand the kids had taken and were keen to show their support, said Ms Thomas. ldquoThey agreed that government at all levels is not doing enough to stop dangerous levels of global warming and climate change.ldquoScientists say we have less than  years to prevent warming going over . degrees, so we need to take drastic measures now. title: Disaled workers getting a raw deal new report claims
story: MANY disabled people in Scotland have been ldquofrozen out of work due to their condition, according to research by disability charity Leonard Cheshire.Three out of four said they left their jobs because they had not received the support they needed to fulfil their role, and nearly one out of five who applied for a job in the past five years felt the employer had chosen not to consider them for the post because they had a disability.Kenny Shand from Inverness who found himself in this situation, said: ldquoNot everyone is treated with respect. Whether you have additional support needs or not, the system needs to be more transparent. Workplace adjustments donrsquot need to be expensive ndash they just need to be done.Stuart Robertson, director at Leonard Cheshire in Scotland, said the findings lt the lid on a ldquotough and unwelcoming employment landscape.He said: ldquoMost people with disabilities in  remain frozen out of the world of work. They always make sure they receive any deliveries before am which really helps and means the construction isnrsquot impacting the children. Thatrsquos the most important thing.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Funding blow to Highland food banks charity
story: North-based charity Blythswood Care has issued a public appeal for more donations after it lost an annual pound, recycling grant from Highland Council in the recent local authority budget.The charity which has one of the largest networks of food banks in the Highlands handles around  tonnes of clothing donations a year at its Evanton depot of which more than  per cent was reused or recycled.Previously the council financially supported the recycling work and some local authority properties already host textile banks for taking unwanted clothing deposits but this year withdrew support.The council had to plug an almost pound million financial hole in its budget amid shrinking government grants for core services, the moves was called a ldquobody blow by operations manager Ian Matheson who admitted the loss of the recycling grant is not a complete surprise.ldquoWe recognise that the Council has been faced with hard decisions. Wersquove enjoyed a mutually beneficial partnership with Highland Council for over  years and we really appreciate that, he said.ldquoTheir support has enabled us to develop our re-use and recycling activities, reducing waste, providing local employment and raising support for projects such as Blythswoodrsquos Highland Food Bank.ldquoDonations of clothing, bric-a-brac and quality furniture from the general public are going to be more important to us than ever as we aim to continue this aspect of our work despite the loss of this grant.The organisation processes more than , tonnes of donations a year at its Evanton depot, producing goods for its charity shops and selling on to processors in other parts of the country.Mr Matheson said ldquoWe have to constantly review all that we do and consider what efficiencies we can make. You can help us now by giving our shops your custom and donations.ldquoAll donations will be gratefully received so we can have continuity of employment ndash because this is about jobs too ndash as well as maintain service provision.A council spokeswoman said: ldquoWe have had very positive discussions with Blythswood and these are ongoing about how we can possibly work together in the future.Blythswood welcomes donations of textiles, footwear, bric-a-brac, small electrical goods, books and good quality furniture.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Highland Council investing extra in roads maintenance
story: Highland Council is hoping an additional pound. million for maintenance announced as part of this yearrsquos budget will make a ldquonoticeable dference across the region.The funding, approved as a priority area for the revenue budget, will be shared out across Highland with area committees able to decide how to prioritise it more locally.Chairman of the councilrsquos environment, development and infrastructure committee, Councillor Allan Henderson, said: ldquoWe have the most extensive network of roads in the UK and, added to this, we are faced with some of the most severe weather conditions in the Highlands.ldquoThe freeze-thaw conditions in particular cause immense damage to road surfaces and this is very evident in the past few weeks.ldquoRoad conditions are a high priority for local residents and this was very clear in our recent engagement with communities and local representatives.ldquoThe additional resource will, I hope, make a noticeable dference and can be allocated to the roads with the most urgent need of repairs, right across the Highlands.Area allocations based on road mileage and population are:Badenoch  Strathspey: pound, Caithness: pound,Inverness: pound, Lochaber: pound, Nairn: pound,Ross  Cromarty: pound,Isle of Skye: pound,Sutherland: pound,Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Historic Inverness city centre mosaics almost completed
story: FINAL measurements have been taken for the re-installation of a well-known Inverness mosaic.Restoration work to breathe le into the historic mosaics in Invernessrsquos Academy Street started in July last year.It came after Cairngorm Taverns secured an Inver-ness Townscape Heritage grant to fully restore the former AI Welders building, which is set to have a street-level bar and first-floor restaurant.It appointed conservation specialist Laing Traditional Masonryas its main contractor although the first phase of work has been handled by sub-contractor the Mosaic Restoration Company .The mosaic of welders and foundry men at work was partially taken down last year by Northamptonshire-based MRC. Mosaics have been taken to MRCrsquos factory for restoration ndash and as one of the four original mosaics was missing, the firm has used a photograph from the s to recreate the original design.MRCrsquos Gary Bricknell described it as a fascinating project for the family-run firm and he looks forward to putting the work back in place next month.ldquoItrsquos been an really interesting job, he said. ldquoEvery one of the tiles is hand-cut for these arches which are about four or five square metres. Wersquove used tens of thousands of tiles and wersquove been working on it for over six months now.Inverness Townscape Heritage Project provided a pound, grant towards the restoration of the B-listed building which is set to open in September as a showcase for Cairngorm and Loch Ness breweries.Sam Fairclf, managing director at Cairngorm Brewery which is involved with Cairngorm Taverns, said: ldquoWe are looking to showcase as much Highland produce as possible.The building was originally the head office of the Rose Street Foundry and Engineering Company and changed to AI Welders in the s.This project is the first major investment by the Inverness Townscape Heritage Project, which is a partnership regeneration project focusing on Academy Street.The refurbishment is a collaboration of funding partners including Inverness City Heritage Trust , Historic Environment Scotland and the Heritage Lottery Fund.Alison Tanner of ICHT said: ldquoThis is not just an interesting project, it is specialist restoration, repair and reinstatement work and needs to be rejoiced.ldquoIt has been years in the planning, the local public are passionate about the mosaics and the building as a whole and this work will save them for future generations.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Hotel plan for Inverness car park site
story: PLANS which would see a city centre car park transformed into a six-storey hotel have been unveiled.The pound million proposal by developer SRP Inverness Ltd was displayed to the public at the Spectrum Centre on Farraline Park, immediately next to the two-deck Rose Street car park which is earmarked as the site for the -metre high hotel.The proposal is the latest city hotel development from SRP Inverness directors Stewart Campbell and Stuart McCaffer, who were also behind the creation of the Inverness Encore Hotel, now the Pentahotel, on nearby Academy Street.Mr Campbell is confident the -bedroom L-shaped building will attract interest from a globally-known hotel brand, bringing something new to the Inverness accommodation mix.ldquoWe have worked with a number of global brands over the years, he said.ldquoInverness has massive global tourism and a lot of people, particularly global travellers, want the comfort of a well-known global brand.ldquoInverness is a strong tourism market, but therersquos been a lack of supply over the years. Other than the Travelodge on Academy Street in , there hasnrsquot been a new hotel built in Inverness since .The proposal includes a gym, three retail units within the hotel footprint and parking for  cars.Mr Campbell believes the hotel will benefit from its proximity to Inverness bus and railway stations, while any under capacity at the car park would be compensated by the nearby multi-storey car park.Mr Campbell and Mr McCaffer also own the neighbouring Rose Street Hall, which they hope to utilise for retail or restaurant use once the hotel is completed.Between the two, they also plan to construct a new bus and taxi road, replacing the footpath linking the bus station and Rose Street retail units.SRP Inverness expects to apply for planning permission in mid-April.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Inverness MP calls for cross party approach to secure post Brexit funding
story: INVERNESS MP Drew Hendry has issued a cross-party rally cry ahead of Brexit.He has written to the Scotland spokespeople of each of the main political parties urging them to put pressure on the UK government to prevent Scotland losing out on millions of pounds in EU funding,the UK leaves the EU.Mr Hendry, the SNPs business spokeman, has called on parties to work together to ensure the UK government delivers a like-for-like replacement for vital EU development funds in the event of Brexit.Mr Hendry said: ldquoCommunities across Scotland would be hit hard by the loss of millions of pounds in vital EU fundingthe UK government drags us out of the EU against our will."The best way to protect this funding is for Scotland to remain in the EU - as we voted overwhelmingly for - butBrexit does go ahead then the UK government must commit to replacing every single penny of the funding Scotland stands to lose."It is shocking that the UK government has already broken its own word, and failed to consult on detailed plans to replace the lost EU funding and the huge benefits it brings for Scotland.ldquoIn addition to the many other benefits of our EU membership, Scotland has enjoyed huge investment in jobs, communities and infrastructure from European funds. It is vital that this investment continues like-for-like, and that the Scottish Government continues to oversee the funding so it meets Scotlands needs.ldquoAt present, groups across the country need to make decision about their future, but have no idea what sort of funding will be available after . This must not be another power grab away from the Scottish Parliament.ldquoSome of this funding helps level the playing field of regional inequality, which is stark when comparing rural areas with urban parts. The Tories must be held to account, investment levels must be matched, and clarity must be given to communities across Scotland.ldquoThe UK government cannot continue to kick this issue into the long grass and weasel out of their responsibilities. It is time for MPs and MSPs of all parties to demand that this money is protected in full and in time to give certainty to communities across Scotland."Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Opinion divided on how to tackle Inverness gull menace
story: TIDY streets could be a more effective deterrent to Invernessrsquos seagull menace than culling, according to the RSPB.The suggestion comes in response to a call for a limited cull by city businessman Charlie Barbour.Mr Barbour, who owns city centre bars The White House and The Dog House as well as commercial property agency Barbour Commercial, suggests that destroying a small number of nesting pairs would make the centre of Inverness more attractive, safer and quieter.Describing the birds as ldquonoisy, dirty, aggressive and a blight on the city centre, Mr Barbour questions whether the Inverness Business Improvement Districtpolicy of removing eggs each year is enough to permanently reduce the gull population.ldquoWhilst a cull of such birds is not a universally popular decision, I just wonderthere is merit in destroying say three or four nesting pairs of seagulls each year, he writes.ldquoA reduction in seagull numbers would improve the city centre experience for visitors and that surely has to be a good thing However, a spokeswoman for conservation charity the RSPB said that lethal control should only ever be a last resort, used only where there is a proven problem and other alternatives have proven ineffective. Instead, local authorities, businesses and iniduals should tackle the problem by reducing the birdsrsquo food supply by cutting down the amount of edible litter and introducing gull-proof litter bins.Other non-lethal options include putting up physical barriers such as netting on roofs as a deterrent before the breeding season.ldquoWe believe that gull problems in an urban environment are best tackled by reducing the availability of food and nest sites. If the features that attract gulls remain, any `vacanciesrsquo created by controlling existing gulls will simply be filled by other gulls moving in, she said.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Roads not safe for city cyclists says Inverness campaigner
story: A LOT needs to be done to bring roads in Inverness up to a standard that makes them safe and easy for road users to navigate, a leading cycling campaigner has said.Brian MacKenzie, convener of the Highland Cycle Campaign, said: ldquoI cycle a lot and there is no doubt the roads in the town are in very poor condition.ldquoThe trunk roads, too, need attention.Championing the cause for better and safer routes for cyclists he said drivers also need to be aware of cyclists and give greater consideration to them.ldquoDrivers often criticise cyclists when they see them weaving along certain routes but often they are doing that simply to avoid potholes and are taking evasive action, he said.ldquoAt the Raigmore Interchange, on the ramp joining the A south from the A, there is a pothole which has been there for some time. It is now gathering water and there is a warning sign for traffic alerting them to flooding.ldquoThere are also two more long potholes which are much more dangerous for cyclists and motorists just as you enter the interchange off the northbound ramp, coming from the Beechwood direction of the A.ldquoThe seal between the interchange and the ramp has gone andyou are cycling along there on a dark night you canrsquot see it, so your wheel can get caught up in it. These are like tram lines and they could throw you off a bike and cause serious injury.ldquoEvery vehicle coming from the A has to go across these potholes as they enter the interchange as well and they have been like that for a considerable time.ldquoI am wondering when the trunk roads people are going to carry out these repairs.While Highland Council is responsible for the upkeep of most roads in Inverness and the surrounding towns and villages, Bear Scotland is responsible for trunk roads.A spokesman for the organisation told the Courier last week that major defects, including deeppotholes which could pose a danger to road users, are repaired within  days, with safety inspections of all roads under its care inspected on a weekly basis.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Stonework to be refurbished at Invernesss Victorian Market
story: Stonework at the Academy Street entrance to Invernesss Victorian Market is to be refurbished at a cost of pound,.The sum will be coveredby grants from the Academy Street Townscape Heritage Trust andInverness Common Good Fund .The decision to push ahead with the project will mean a delay to other planned mechanical and electrical works, alongwith the installation ofnew doors at the market.pound, remains allocated towards the upgrading of shopfronts at the market, including new lighting and flooring.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: mcinnes looks for home comforts
story: Aberdeen may have equalled a club record winning streak on the road but boss Derek McInnes has called for an end to their Pittodrie slump.The - win at St Johnstone was the Reds’ seventh straight victory away from home in all competitions.It matched the previous club best set in  and .The Dons also boast the best away form in the Scottish Premiership with  points from  games.Yet at Pittodrie the Dons have taken just two points from the last possible .McInnes has called for that slump to end tomorrow when hosting Hamilton.He said: “It is great we have managed to equal that club record.“Especially when you think of some of the great Aberdeen teams there have been in the history at our club.“It says a lot about our players and their intent on the road.“We have always been a decent away team and always been quite strong at Pittodrie.“Since the turn of the year it has not been as free-flowing and straightforward at home.“But at St Johnstone it was illustrated when we play at tempo and have space to work in that we are a good team.“That has been the key to the away games.“However, you have to work for that space.“What we have to do against Hamilton is generate the same speed and intensity we did at St Johnstone.“But also have the calmness and composure when teams come up and sit off us.”Relegation-battling Hamilton will arrive at Pittodrie on the back of a - hammering from Rangers on Sunday.Aberdeen remained five points behind second-placed Rangers with the victory over St Johnstone in Perth.McInnes was pleased with the Reds’ performance and result after the disappointment of dropping points to bottom side St Mirren in the previous match.He said: “That was another big victory for us.“When you start to run out of league games you want to make sure that you maximise everything you have from your season.“It was important we had to make up for last week against St Mirren.“I was really pleased.“Last week I was frustrated as we felt we squandered two points at home.“We tried to make up for that by getting the three points back at St Johnstone.“I watched St Johnstone’s game against Rangers and they were very good.“We knew the dficulty of the task in coming to Perth.“They started better than us as I thought we were a wee bit limp in one or two of the challenges.“It was important that we quicken our minds up and played the game at the level we needed to play it at.“Once we got the first goal we were in charge of the game.“St Johnstone had to change as Tommytries to go -- and we dealt with that.“it allowed us more space to work and we were just kicking ourselves that we hadn’t got that second goal before it came.“Then Shinnie scored it with a very good finish off his left side, his natural side.“From then on in we looked like a very experienced team and managed the game.“A clean sheet and three points and a very good performance, I couldn’t ask for any more.”

title: changes in jet stream set to bring colder weather to north east
story: While the north-east, and much of the UK enjoys unseasonably warm weather, the Met Office has warned it looks set to change.Later this week the jet stream, which is responsible for the country seeing record temperatures is to change shape.Scotland basks in warmest February day on record as temperature hits .C" src"https:www.eveningexpress news scotland scotland-basks-in-warmest-february-day-on-record-as-temperature-hits--c embed # secretwiDYgULeWR" data-secret"wiDYgULeWR" width"" "" title"#Scotland basks in warmest February day on record as temperature hits .C# # Evening Express" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"At the moment the #meandering# jet stream is bringing warm air across the UK.However, as  the weekend approaches it will begin to flatten.This change will make the weather less mild and more changeable.Across the country, Wednesday is expected to start foggy with some frost but it is expected to be dry and bright throughout the day.Heavy showers are possible on Thursday as temperatures struggle to breach Cor C .Friday, March , will mark the first day of meteorological spring and is expected to be mostly dry before a wet weekend.

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: jury asked convict ayr broadcaster
story: NewsJury asked to convict Ayr broadcaster Bryce Curdy on girl rape chargeHis defence claims evidence against him "doesnt stack up"ShareByStephen Houston:,  FEB NewsThe trial is taking place at the High Court in Glasgow "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA PROSECUTOR has urged a jury to convict broadcaster Bryce Curdy of raping a -year-old girl in the South of France. Liam Ewing told jurors: “You have heard how the girl described screaming as he raped her.” He added: “I ask you to examine the evidence. She goes into a lot of detail about what happened to her. I invite you toa guilty verdict.” The alleged victim, who is now , claimed that Curdy, , from Ayr, raped her three times. She alleged that on each occasion he whispered to her afterwards” If you tell anyone I will kill you and your mum.” Curdy, who is on trial at the High Court in Glasgow, denies raping her on ious occasions between April  and August , , at a house in the South of France. Mr Ewing told the jury that the Crown is relying on testimony from the girls mother, who is , to corroborate the rape. She alleges that Curdy also raped her in August  in the South of France. The mothers allegation, which he denies, is not before the jury. Under Scots Law alleged crimes against children committed in another country can be prosecuted here, but not those against adults. The mother claimed that after having consensual sex with her, Curdy went on to rape her. Defence counsel Lorenzo Alonzi told the jury: “If you apply the law, you will find that the correct verdict in this case is acquittal.” Mr Alonzi said in his closing speech that there was absolutely no independent evidence in this case – only the allegations of the girl and her mother. He went on: “There is no DNA evidence, there is no torn clothing, there is no medical evidence and no witnesses who heard screams. “The idea that there was this monstrous threat to kill her and her mum, it doesnt stack up.” Curdy claimed that the two woman made up the allegations about him after he demanded theof his pound, gold and diamond Rolex watch. The trial before judge Johanna Johnston QC continues.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSex crimeGlasgowAyrCourtsJusticeAyr News

title: scotlands king cone philip mancini
story: NewsScotlands "King Cone" Philip Mancini scoops Ice Cream Alliances national contestDessert guru wins first place for his blackcurrant sorbetShareByGary Fanning:,  FEB News"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailScotland’s“King Cone” has licked the opposition again. Philip Mancini won first place for his blackcurrant sorbet dessert in the Ice Cream Alliance’s national contest. The dessert guru, who runs Mancini’s Ice Cream in Ayr, has already been crowned UK champion ice cream maker three times and won numerous awards for his products over the years. Philip said: “I’m always delighted to win these ICA awards as you’re competing against the very best in the business. “It comes after a great year for Mancini’s and the industry as a whole. “A great summer like we had in  is always good news for us and we’ve an exciting  ahead too.” The latest success marks the start of what Philip hopes will be a new chapter in his ice cream dynasty as he prepares to open a beach-front cafe in Prestwick in April. Philip said: “I told my family I was going to spend more time on the golf course . “But I can’t stay away from ice cream. “I put our success down to Italian flavours combined with the best quality Scottish dairy products and generations of experience handed down from father to son.” As well as the new cafe, the grandfather-of-three looks set for a record year supplying romance-themed ices to wedding across Scotland. The specialist treats include Jamaican Me Crazy, made with exotic fruits, a strawberry and prosecco sorbet and an alluring dark chocolate and raspberry creation. The ICA National Ice Cream Competition recognises the best manufacturers and vendors from across the UK and Ireland.
