title: Iain Macwhirter  Get over it - cis women are just on the wrong side of history
story: This, apparently, is to educate heteronormative women about their ldquoprivilege ndash the fact that they can use the toilets, sorry ldquowashrooms, of their choice and access healthcare. Irsquom not sure who exactly has been preventing transgender women using public conveniences. So far as I know, you donrsquot have to show a birth certicate, or undergo a medical exam to have a pee. But what do I know as a pale, stale male.What I do know is that ldquocis-gender is an ugly neologism which many women find offensive. They are content with their present sexual terminology. ldquoCis is in the same linguistic ballpark as ldquoTERF ndash trans exclusionary radical feminist, which is a term of abuse used against women who believe persons with penises are, er, male. I should be careful here because a number of TERFS have been banned from social media for saying that a person with a penis is a man. So I wonrsquot say that.Instead, letrsquos just take it as read that in future we are going to have to accept that the concept of sexual dferentiation with which we have been living for thousands of years is finally being exposed as a malign transphobic hood. At any rate, the Scottish Government appears determined to press ahead with reform of the Gender Recognition Act, which will allow trans people to assign themselves legally and biologically female. Hitherto, trans people have had to undergo medical examination and get a diagnosis of ldquogender dysphoria. No more. From now on, anyone can change their birth certicate to whatever they wish.Earlier this month, Holyroodrsquos culture committee warned that ending binary ldquoMale or Female questions in the Scottish census will render much of the results meaningless and, willy nilly, import an unscientic definition of sex into the law. But the Scottish Government is not listening. Nicola Sturgeon told a UN equalities conference last week that the concerns of feminists about the GRA are ldquomisplaced.Women ndash sorry, ldquomenstruators ndash who say that self-ID erases their sexual identity will be told: just get over it. They can complain that ldquosex is a protected characteristic under the  Equalities Act, and that women therefore have a right to their own unique spaces. But now that men can actually become women under the law, this right will be impossible to articulate. Trans women with male anatomy will be entitled to enter womenrsquos changing rooms, girl guide troops or womenrsquos prisons. Women who complain will be guilty of transphobia, and are likely to be visited by the police recording a ldquohate incident.Now, I have nothing against adults changing their gender, or identying as women, queer, non-binary, intersex or whatever. It seems to be reinforcing outmoded concepts of gender to suggest that, because someone wants to wear dresses, play with dolls and put on makeup, they must have a lady brain in a male body. I thought we had left pink-for-girls gender stereotyping behind. But never mind. No-one wishes trans people any ill ndash certainly not me. But now that we are abandoning the very biological definition of sex, there are some anomalies that need to be addressed.Last week, a British transgender man, who had IVF by sperm donation and gave birth, won a court battle to prevent his child having ldquomother on its birth certicate. It will be the first child in history to have no mother. The The AIRE Centre, a human rights charity, contested this on the grounds that it would make le dficult for the child in future, when they apply for visas or anything which enquires about family background. The Government said simply that this isnrsquot a problem. From now on, fathers can give birth ndash end of.But Irsquom not sure this is the end of the matter. Children have not been included in the gender recognition debate thus far, even though they have rights too. It could be psychologically disturbing for a child to find, one day, that its mother has decided to become its dad. That song ldquoSometimes I feel like a motherless child takes on a whole new meaning.Of course, the trans parent will still be present, but is it OK to expect a child to suddenly start calling her natural mother her father  I would have thought that a child has a continuing right to a legal motherthey were born with one. If misgendering a trans person is unacceptable, surely demothering a child should be too. This is going to be confusing to say the least.Then there is the question of sport. The controversy over athlete Caster Semenya, a woman with high testosterone, raises the question of how to regard trans womenrsquos participation in women-only sport. Athletes who have testes, and therefore posses greater body mass, muscle strength and bone density, have an unfair advantage over old-fashioned women who have genetically female bodies.Next week, the International Association of Athletics Federations will argue in a hearing in Switzerland that people like Semenya should take testosterone-suppressing drugs before competing. Not only would this drive a coach and horses through the anti-doping protocols, it surely poses problem for transgender athletes who, of course, also take drugs like testosterone to help them transition to their ldquocorrect male sex. I hope the sporting authorities can get their heads around that because I canrsquot.Yet this is a very live issue in many sports. In the US, the ban on trans women taking part in power-lting events is being lted to prevent accusations of discrimination. You might have thought that having beefy, male-bodied women participating in these contests is discriminating against women athletes. Though, of course, only transphobes would say that, so we wonrsquot go there.The logical solution to this conundrum is to end sexual segregation in sport. Andwomen who are born biologically female never win any medals, tough. Strangely, there doesnrsquot seem to be the same issue about female-bodied trans men participating in male-only sport . Irsquom sure that has nothing whatever to do with the fact that they wonrsquot win anything.So welcome to the brave new world of post-sexual dferentiation, where men become women and fathers have children. It is one of the most radical and abrupt cultural changes in human history.Women have had a pretty bad deal in previous centuries, when they were regarded often as chattels without rights. In some Muslim societies theyrsquore still second-class citizens. Now, as women are finally emerging from the shadow of patriarchy, they are being told, by men, that they no longer have exclusive rights to their sexual identity.Itrsquos a weird turn of events. It seems women are just on the wrong side of history. But somehow, I donrsquot think theyrsquoll go quietly.

title: Rosemary Goring  Now is the time for the Catholic Church   s own Reformation
story: For this book Martel has conducted more than , interviews in the Vatican City in Rome, and across the world. He has spoken to priests, cardinals, bishops, monsignors, papal ambassadors, seminarians and the Swiss Guard. His conclusion, which will shock some and come as no surprise to others, is that about  per cent of the clergy in the Vatican state are gay. In other words, the HQ of a church that will not bless same-sex relationships, and forbids its clergy to have sex lives, is riddled with hyprocisy at its very core.Of these  per cent, Martel writes, some are celibate or in denial, others are living with their partners, or resort to prostitutes. A rule of thumb is that the more vehemently a cleric condemns homosexuality, the more likely he is to be in the closet himself. Hence the behaviour of the Colombian cardinal, Alfonso Lopez Trujillo. He was in the vanguard of the churchrsquos mission to prevent gay marriage. As the dire consequences of the Aids epidemic became clear, contrary to commonsense and compassion, he refused to encourage the use of condoms. Here was someone eager to be seen to uphold traditional values. Yet Martel claims that Trujillo, who died in , used male prostitutes.There are examples closer to home, among them the late Cardinal Keith OrsquoBrien, who pursued a similarly denunciatory anti-gay agenda, despite his own homosexuality and predatory behaviour. In fact, it doesnrsquot matter where you look. Throughout the Catholic churchrsquos parishes, globally and locally, there has been the mother of all cover-ups, not just in the buttoned-up past, but right now, here, today.You could say the church has been built on lies: countless men forced to hide who they really are, or to seek refuge in an all-male environment where they could find illicit love behind closed doors. Those clergy who were straight must have found themselves in a bewildering labyrinth of duplicity. That such depths of deceit have been allowed to thrive says all you need to know about the controlling power of those at the heart of the church.Martel believes that Pope Francis has earned enemies by adopting a very untypical approach. ldquoWho am I to judge  he replied, when askedhe condemned homosexuals, thereby loosening the ground beneath the feet of those in the Holy See who donrsquot want their secrets aired, or their way of le altered.The revelation of such widespread double standards is an echo of the medieval churchrsquos calamitous abuse of power and wealth. Out of it has sprung a culture where bullying, intimidation and blackmail have flourished. Andthat has been going on in this sphere, you can be sure it will have spilled over into every other part of the churchrsquos affairs.In the wake of the revelation of child abuse on a grand scale in the church, you begin to see why hiding the truth was the default position. This is not to make a link between homosexuality and child abuse but to see why the ecclesiastical authorities were so quick, and adept, at making the problem disappear. In avoiding scandal, they were intent on protecting their own rather than those who had been so grievously harmed.With evidence of institutionalised deception of the extent Martel claims, the church brings shame on itself: not for the numbers of priests who are gay, but for the willingness to lie about it, and to break vows, and the spirit of vocation, to an extent that will appall devout parishioners.Now is the time for the Catholic Churchrsquos own Reformation. No-one can any longer doubt that the le expected of a Catholic priest is unhealthy. And since there is no biblical injunction on him to be celibate, why can this not be changed  Already the church is embracing married Anglican vicars in flight from the ordination of women. Why not allow Catholic clergy the same right to open relationships, whether they be gay or straight Until the double-speak on which the modern church stands is addressed, there is no hope of winning back the faithful who have lost all trust and respect in this once revered institution. Obliging men to profess one thing while being another, is psychological torment. The denial of clergyrsquos humanity and self-expression is as cruel as anything the Inquisition devised. If the Vatican could bring itself to accept homosexuality, and gay marriage, and a non-celibate priesthood, it would be a truly Christian act.Read more: Cardinal Keith OBrien asked for forgiveness

title: Marianne Taylor  Last chance for Mundell to put country before party
story: The majority of these demands are perfunctory, of course, made in the knowledge and expectation that they will be ignored by the target, while playing well with the initiatorrsquos supporters.The craziness of the last few months has precipitated a flurry of genuine and warranted resignation demands, however, which under normal political circumstances would have resulted in multiple ministerial heads rolling in any other era the Prime Minister would have been forced out long ago.Marianne Taylor: BBC is better off without Neil and HumphrysAnother case in point is Scottish Secretary David Mundell, whose stubborn insistence on being ineffectual in the face of the biggest crisis this country has faced in generations is matched only by that of Jeremy Corbyn. Mr Mundellrsquos wan smiles and empty words about doing the best for Scotland as the Government he is a member of readies itself to push us off the no-deal Brexit clf, is as astonishing as it is appalling. He, too, should have gone months ago, not least over the manner in which his party has arrogantly steamrollered over the views and interests of the country he supposedly represents.Read more: Mundell should resign there is no-deal BrexitRemarkably still in post, Mr Mundell now has one last chance to make a meaningful contribution to the ridiculous and dangerous situation the Westminster parliament has created for itself. The SNP is right to call for Mr Mundell to show some mettle and make clear that he will not serve in a Government that is willing to take us out of the European Union without a deal, a situation that would put the already fragile Scottish economy on the road to ruin. As the Scottish Secretary is well aware, businesses will fail, jobs will be lost and real people will suffer the sort of real hardships that will be dficult to recover from.Marianne Taylor: BBC is better off without Neil and HumphrysSNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford has written to Mr Mundell, laying out the gravity of the situation and calling on him to back growing cross-party demands to halt the Brexit process by extending Article  and making clear to his boss, Theresa May, that he will resign unless she faces up the extremists in her party and takes no-deal off the table.At this critical juncture, the least that the people of Scotland deserve from the man who represents them at Cabinet level is honesty about where his loyalties lie: will he put country or party first  Mr Mundell, it really is that simple.Read more: Mundell should resign there is no-deal BrexitOf course, Mr Blackfordrsquos letter also highlights the bleakness of the dilemma facing the SNP. If Mrs May gets her way and Parliament is faced with a last-minute binary choice between her terrible deal - which deprives us of the key benefits being in the EU - and an even more catastrophic no-deal, it leaves the party in a dficult position. How should Nicola Sturgeon instruct her MPs to vote in this scenario  Backing Mrs Mayrsquos ldquomy way or the highway deal would be criticised by many as a U-turn of epic proportions and a sign of weakness. Not voting for it, and thus facilitating a no-deal Brexit, would likely be viewed by many voters as unforgivable, leaving the party open to allegations that this is the outcome it has been secretly hoping for all along, in order to boost support for independence.Ms Sturgeon and her colleagues will be hoping the growing number of Tory ministers and backbench MPs ndash including Cabinet secretaries Amber Rudd, Greg Clarke and David Gauke - poised to revolt against their leader should she refuse to rule out a no-deal Brexit, will come to their rescue in the frantic days and weeks to come.Marianne Taylor: BBC is better off without Neil and HumphrysThe emergence of the The Independent Groupmay also end up helping the SNPrsquos predicament, at least in the short term. Formed last week when eight MPs resigned from Labour unhappy at Mr Corbynrsquos disastrous leadership, it did not initially appear to be an important development. But when three Tory MPs also resigned and joined up, using the moment to launch a blistering attack on Mrs Mayrsquos disastrous Brexit strategy and their partyrsquos lurch to the right, it started to feel more signicant.What binds these MPs from dferent sides of the House of Commons is dismay at the drt of both parties to the extremities. And despite not being a proper party - yet - or having any actual policiesit seems many voters quite like what they see.Read more: Mundell should resign there is no-deal BrexitMomentum has grown over the weekend, with polls already putting the group on  per cent, just one behind the increasingly irrelevant Lib Dems.Many are asking whether TIG has a future. Surely, however, whatrsquos most important is the future of the country, andthis new movement serves only to facilitate the halting of Article , so that a new road out of the current mess can be found, then it will already have done more for the UK than Mr Corbyn. Or indeed Mr Mundell for that matter.

title: public-health-experts-call-for-ban-on-army-recruiting-under-18s
story: More than one in fivepeople joining the UK army are children aged  to , but experts are calling for the age threshold to be raised.Read more: Army on standby in preparation for no-deal BrexitThe UK is the only European country and permanent member of the UN Security Council to recruit -year-olds.Children as young as  can begin the enlistment process, with two years of training starting from the age of  prior to first deployment at .Writing today in the journal, BMJ Open Paediatrics, the researchers from charity Medact say that current recruitment practices "capitalise on a window of vulnerability" during adolescence, and disproportionately target youngsters from the lowest socioeconomic groups.Read more: Avoidable deaths among children and teens in Scotland highest in UKReem Abu-Hayyeh, of Medact, and Dr Guddi Singh, an integrated child health specialist, said military service at this age exposes them to the risk of long lasting and complex effects on mental and physical health.They said evidence shows younger recruits more vulnerable to self-harm, suicide, and alcohol misuse, associated with the isolation and culture of military le as well as the trauma of active combat.Read more: Childrens commissioner says youths from deprived backgrounds should not be targeted by Army recruitmentThe British Army says it is facing a personnel shortfall of  but the researchers insist the recruitment policy is "misguided and counterproductive", pointing to figures showing that those recruited under  account for % of those who leave the Armed Forces voluntarily before completing their service.Concerns have previously been raised in Scotland about the Ministry of Defence targeting recruitment drives to schools in deprived communities.

title: david-pratt-outsiders-are-playing-fast-and-loose-with-the-fate-of-venezuela
story: A military escalation is the last thing the country needs, but such are the high stakes for both sides in this struggle for power there seems an increasing readiness to go down that route.The ldquoall options are on the table talk that some weeks ago characterised the rhetoric coming out of Washington in support of the Venezuelan opposition and echoed in response by the government of President Nicolas Maduro, now has a distinctly scary ring.Yesterday Venezuelan opposition leader Juan Guaido only added to that fear as he met US Vice President Mike Pence and asked other countries to consider ldquoall options to remove President Maduro from power.Mr Guidorsquos request in all likelihood will only further intensy a violent situation on the ground that last weekend saw clashes between opposition forces and security forces as well as armed supporters loyal to Mr Maduro that led to several deaths and hundreds being injured.The most dramatic scenes unfolded on Saturday on the bridges connecting the Colombian city of Cucuta to Venezuelan towns across the Tachira River.There, Mr Guaido, now recognised by dozens of countries as Venezuelarsquos legitimate interim president, called for convoys of humanitarian aid to be let into his beleaguered nation.For weeks Mr Guaido trumpeted the day as the moment when Venezuelarsquos long-suffering people would get the aid they so desperately needed. But some say what might have been a masterplan to increase pressure on Mr Maduro has only pushed the country down an even more chaotic course towards civil war.It was a gesture say critics of Mr Guaido that had more to do with provocation than humanitarianism and which left some global organisations like the UN and the International Committee of the Red Crosswarning all sides of the dangers in ldquoweaponising aid. Perhaps the most worrying aspect in all of this however is the apparent willingness of other outside players to play fast and loose with the fate of Venezuela and its people.Just what did US Senator Mark Rubio think would be the outcome of him posting two photographs of former Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi on his Twitter account on Sunday Itrsquos well known of course that Mr Rubio is an influential voice in Washington on Venezuela policy and a staunch critic of Mr Maduro. But his tweet showing the Libyan leader bloodied and injured shortly before his death at the hands of rebel militiamen is the crudest and most incendiary of messages to Mr Maduro.That Mr Rubio had previously tweeted another photo of former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega, who was captured in  after a US military invasion, is likewise unequivocal it its meaning and can, as intended, only be read one way by Mr Maduro. The message is simple, your time is up and forcenecessary, will be used.How Mr Rubio and those in Washington think such gestures strengthen their case for democratic change in Venezuela is baffling. Surely rather that stoke an already dangerously volatile situation, the US government should be doing all it can to ensure that such a process happens through the ballot box The Trump administration is now clearly losing patience with Mr Maduro and no longer cares how he is removed from office so long as he is and their chosen leader Mr Guaido takes over.Just last week President Trump at a speech in Miami urged ldquoVenezuelan patriots to rise up against the regime. Mr Guaido at the weekend did the same on Twitter.ldquoTodayrsquos events force me to make a decision to formally propose to the international community that we must have all options open to secure the freedom our country.For many Latin America analysts such talk bodes ill and presents serious warning signs.ldquoThere is no question that a military intervention to resolve the Venezuela crisis is more plausible than ever, Michael Shter, president of the Inter-American Dialogue, a US-based think- tank, told the Washington Post over the last few days as the crisis deepened.ldquoGuaidorsquos insistence that lsquoall options are on the tablersquo echoes President Trumprsquos words, first uttered in August  and widely interpreted as serious consideration of military action, warned Mr Shter.Some observers however insist that the US history of attempted regime change in the Latin American region and Mr Trumprsquos loose language are both working against the opposition that faces a still formidable foe in Mr Madurorsquos regime.Many Venezuelans remain suspicious of Washingtonrsquos motives, evenyet more defections to the opposition from within the ranks of the Venezuelan security forces have taken place over the past few days.More than  members of Venezuelarsquos armed forces defected during the clashes last weekend, with Mr Guaido promising the defectors would be given amnesty and congratulating them on joining ldquothe right side of history.Mr Maduro meanwhile still believes himself to be on the right side of history evenlast weekendrsquos blockade of foreign aid has left him facing a diplomatic siege.As the crisis worsens UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres has appealed for ldquoviolence to be avoided at any cost and insisted everyone should lower tensions.Washington however is paying little heed and more than ever seems intent in doing whatever it takes to get its way in Venezuela. ldquoThe eyes of the entire world are upon you today, every day, and every day in the future, Mr Trump told Mr Madruo in a speech last week. ldquoYou cannot hide from the choice that now confronts you, the US president warned.For now all eyes are on the outcome of yesterdayrsquos meeting in the Colombian capital Bogota between Mr Pence and Mr GuaidoIf indeed all options are on the table, as both men have made clear, then Venezuela might be about to face the most dangerous moment in this crisis so far. What an even greater catastrophe it would beUS military intervention were the option chosen.

title: scotland-could-lose-730m-in-post-brexit-funding-without-replacement-cash-says-analysis
story: Scotland could lose £m in post-Brexit funding without UK replacement cash, says analysisSNP seeks cross-party support to ensure Whitehall gives #like-for-like replaltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtcement# for EU fltspan classtruncate-full-screengtundsThe SNP is seeking cross-party support to pressure the UK Government into preventing the estimated loss in financial aid of more than poundm.The calculation has come from the Conference of Peripheral Maritime Regions, a think-tank and lobbying organisation, which brings together some  regions from##EU states to campaign for a more balanced development across the continent.Its analysis concludes Brexit would be ldquodisastrous for development, estimating that between  and  Scotland could lose funding worth some poundm ie more than poundm a year.The Nationalist leadership has written to David Mundell, the Scottish Secretary, Lesley Laird, his Labour Shadow, and Christine Jardine of the Liberal Democrats, urging them all to work together to pressure the Conservative Government to ensure that, following the planned transition period, it delivers a ldquolike-for-like replacement for vital EU development funds in the event of Brexit.The SNP has pointed out that while the UK Government has committed to continue aid funding until , there has been no clarity on the so-called Shared Prosperity Fund, the proposed replacement for the EU development funds after this date.Last week, Scottish and Welsh Finance Ministers met with UK Government ministers seeking clarity on future funding arrangements but they insisted none was forthcoming.Drew Hendry, the SNPrsquos Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy spokesman, said: ldquoCommunities across Scotland would be hit hard by the loss of millions of pounds in vital EU fundingthe UK Government drags us out of the EU against our will."The best way to protect this funding is for Scotland to remain in the EU - as we voted overwhelmingly for - butBrexit does go ahead, then the UK Government must commit to replacing every single penny of the funding Scotland stands to lose.Mr Hendry, who represents Inverness, Nairn, Badenoch and Strathspey, said it was shocking that the Government had already broken its own word by failing to consult on detailed plans to replace the lost EU funding and insisted it could not ldquoweasel out of its responsibilities.ldquoIt is time for MPs and MSPs of all parties to demand that this money is protected in full and in time to give certainty to communities across Scotland," he added.A spokesman for the UK Government said it recognised the importance of reassuring communities on the future of local growth funding once Britain left the EU.ldquoWe have guaranteed existing EU funding commitments until the end of  and are making good progress on the design of the UK Shared Prosperity Fund. We will, of course, work in partnership with the devolved administrations to ensure this works for the whole of the UK.The consultation on the Governmentrsquos replacement fund will be published ldquoin due course.

title: brexit-jeremy-corbyn-moves-to-back-second-eu-poll-with-remain-on-ballot-paper
story: The dramatic move came as Theresa Mayrsquos plane touched down following her trip to Egypt when she insisted a deal with Brussels was ldquowithin our grasp.But she placed herself on a collision course with a large number of Tory colleagues, including some in the Cabinet, when she set her face against calls to put back exit day from March  to allow more time for talks.Today, she will update MPs on the ldquoprogress in the Brussels talks key will be the wording of the Government motion to be debated and voted on tomorrow evening.After days of senior figures saying Labour was ldquomoving towards supporting a Peoplersquos Vote, Mr Corbyn announced the sht during a two-hour meeting of the Parliamentary Labour Party at Westminster.He explained Labour would table its own amendment, calling for a customs union with a UK say and close alignment with the single market, and would also support his colleague Yvette Cooperrsquos amendment to extend the Article  process to avoid a no-deal outcome.But, signicantly, the party leader said,those failed, Labour would back an amendment ldquoin favour of a public vote to prevent a damaging Tory Brexit".A senior party source said the ldquoassumption would be that Remain would be on the ballot paper but made clear it would not be a straight choice between the Governmentrsquos deal and Remain as the former was unacceptable ious options were being considered.But not everyone was happy. Backbencher John Mann reportedly claimed people in the North of England would "never vote Labour again". He told Mr Corbyn: ldquoThis decision will stop you being Prime Minister.

title: brexit-stakes-raised-jeremy-corbyn-backs-peoples-vote-and-theresa-may-refuses-to-delay-exit-day
story: As the febrile atmosphere at Westminster intensied ahead of tomorrowrsquos Commons vote, the Prime Minister ed to Britain from her attendance at the EU-Arab summit in Sharm el-Sheikh as the Labour leader was addressing a packed private meeting of the parliamentary party in the Commons.During the two-hour conclave, passionate contributions could be heard from outside the Gladstone Room as journalists waited in the committee corridor.Mr Corbyn told MPs: "The Prime Minister is recklessly running down the clock in an attempt to force MPs to choose between her botched deal and a disastrous no-deal. We cannot and will not accept that.He said Labours alternative Brexit plan - contained in an amendment - for a comprehensive customs union with a UK say, close alignment with the single market and guarantees on rights and standards was ldquoserious and credible.The party leader made clear Labour would also be backing the amendment, proposed by his colleague Yvette Cooper, to extend the Article  process in a bid to rule out a no-deal outcome.ldquoOne way or another, we will do everything in our power to prevent no-deal and oppose a damaging Tory Brexit based on Theresa Mays overwhelmingly rejected deal, declared Mr Corbyn.Then he added: "Thats why, in line with our conference policy, we are committed to also putting forward or supporting an amendment in favour of a public vote to prevent a damaging Tory Brexit being forced on the country."At first there was a deal of confusion as to whether an option to Remain would be on the ballot paper of a Labour-supported Peoplersquos Vote. Some Remainer MPs emerged unsure as they said Mr Corbyn had not been specic about the Remain option in his answers.But others insisted the position was clear. One peer said Remain would ldquoinevitably be on the ballot paper, stressing: ldquoOtherwise what would be the point  You canrsquot have a Peoplersquos Vote with one question.Backbencher Owen Smith, who challenged for the leadership in , said: ldquoThis was always the right policy for Labour. This is where we should have been at the beginning.His Labour colleague Ian Murray, a leading Remainer, described the leadershiprsquos position as ldquounequivocal, adding: ldquoThis is signicant progress and now we must win the arguments to get a majority in Parliament to win a public vote with the option to remain.But some MPs were unhappy. Lucy Powell, who represents Manchester Central, estimated some  colleagues would vote against a second referendum.John Mann, the Nottinghamshire MP, claimed people in the North of England would "never vote Labour again". He told Mr Corbyn: ldquoThis decision will stop you being Prime Minister.Meanwhile, Brandon Lewis, the Conservative Chairman, accused the Labour leadership of having ldquoripped up their promise to respect the referendum result.He added: ldquoJeremy Corbyns Labour want to betray the will of the British people and ignore the biggest democratic vote in our nations history.It is thought part of the Labour leadershiprsquos calculation was to try to stem the defections to the centrist pro-Remain Independent Group, which has seen eight MPs leave Labour to join it.Today, the Government is expected to table the motion for debate tomorrow. While some MPs have suggested Mrs May might try to kill off support for the Cooper amendment by signalling she would not allow the country to crash out of the EU without a deal, she was adamant in Sharm el-Sheikh that she would not support extending Article .The PM told a press conference: ldquoA delay in this process does not deliver a decision in Parliament, it doesnrsquot deliver a deal what it does is precisely what the word says.After a raft of meetings on the sidelines, which included talks with Germanyrsquos Angela Merkel, Irelandrsquos Leo Varadkar and the European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker, Mrs May told journalists: ldquoI have a real sense from the meetings I have had here, conversations I have had with EU leaders in recent dayshellipwe can achieve that deal. Itrsquos within our grasp to leave with a deal on March  and thatrsquos where all our energies are going to be focused.The PM, who has put off having a meaningful vote this week but promised one by March , admitted there was ldquostill more work to do.But she noted: ldquoWhat I have sensed in all of my conversations with my fellow leaders both here in Sharm el-Sheikh and in recent days is a real determination to find a way through, which allows the UK to leave the EU in a smooth and orderly way with a deal.

title: chinas-social-credit-system-a-ratings-nightmare-straight-out-of-black-mirror-or-an-exercise-in-rebuilding-trust
story: ldquoOnce you lose trust,the slogan says, ldquoyou will face restrictions everywhere.By , every citizen will have a centrally-logged lsquosocial creditrsquo score, akin to a credit reference. But it does not just measure their financial standing.So far introduced on a voluntary basispoints are lost for misdemeanours ndash such as failing to pay a fine. But other anti-social behaviour will also be penalised: smoking in the wrong place, posting the the wrong thing on social media, jaywalking or even buying too many video games.Those whose score drops too far could be banned from certain jobs, or enrolling in college. Good scores may make it easier to get loans or visas for foreign travel. But the Government has already banned millions of people with low social credit ratings from air and train travel.

story: Mrs May confirmed that she will put her Withdrawal Agreement, including whatever additional assurances she has secured from Brussels, to a "meaningful vote" by March .If that fails, MPs will be offered two separate votes on the following days - one on a no-deal Brexit and,that is defeated, the other on requesting an extension to the two-year Article  negotiation process to delay EU withdrawal beyond March .Read more: Brexit fallout liveThe sequence of votes will be proposed in an amendable motion tabled by the Prime Minister for debate and vote in the Commons on Wednesday.To uproar in the Commons, Mrs May told MPs: "They are commitments I am making as Prime Minister and I will stick by them, as I have previous commitments to make statements and table amendable motions by specic dates."But she added: "Let me be clear, I do not want to see Article  extended. Our absolute focus should be on working to get a deal and leaving on March ."Read more:Jeremy Corbyn moves to back second EU poll - with Remain on ballot paperIn a statement to MPs following a Cabinet meeting with senior colleagues at  Downing Street, Theresa May said she wanted to set out "three further commitments" to the Commons.She said: "First, we will hold a second meaningful vote by Tuesday March  at the latest."Second,the Government has not won a meaningful vote by Tuesday March , then it will - in addition to its obligations to table a neutral amendable motion under Section  of the EU Withdrawal Act - table a motion to be voted on by Wednesday March  at the latest, asking this Houseit supports leaving the EU without a Withdrawal Agreement and a framework for a future relationship on March ."So the United Kingdom will only leave without a deal on March there is explicit consent in the House for that outcome."Third,the House, having rejected the deal negotiated with the EU, then rejects leaving on March  without a Withdrawal Agreement and future framework, the Government will on March  bring forward a motion on whether Parliament wants to seek a short, limited extension to Article ."If MPs vote for an extension, the Government will "seek to agree that extension approved by the House with the EU, and bring forward the necessary legislation to change the exit date commensurate with that extension", said Mrs May.The Prime Minister said that an extension of Article  beyond the end of June would require the UK to take part in European Parliament elections in May and that a shorter extension would "almost certainly have to be a one-off"."An extension cannot take no-deal off the table," she warned. "The only way to do that is to revoke Article , which I shall not do, or agree a deal."Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said that Mrs May appeared to be adopting the terms of a cross-party amendment put forward by Yvette Cooper and Sir Oliver Letwin designed to prevent no-dealher Withdrawal Agreement is voted down on March .But he told MPs: "Until the Prime Minister is clear what alternative she would put forward in that circumstance, then she is continuing to run down the clock."She promises a short extension but for what "Mr Corbyn confirmed that Labour will table an amendment to the Governments motion calling for a deal based on its priorities of a customs union, close alignment with the single market and matching EU workplace and environmental rights."If the Government wants a genuine renegotiation it should do so on terms that can win a majority of this House, on terms backed by businesses and unions and that are contained within Labours amendment, which I urge the whole House to back tomorrow," he said.The Prime Minister hit out at Mr Corbyn over Labours support for a second referendum."He has gone back on his promise to respect the referendum result and now wants to hold a isive second referendum that would take our country right back to square one," she said."Anyone who voted Labour at the last election because they thought he would deliver Brexit will rightly be appalled."

title: richard-leonard-defies-majority-of-scots-to-back-brexit-over-second-referendum
story: The Scottish Labour leader saidit came to a vote, he would support Remain.THE SNP said the remark would "utterly dismay" many Labour supporters.Labour MP Ian Murray also criticised Mr Leonard, We should have a public vote with the Prime Ministers deal versus remain on the ballot paper, and we must back remain for the sake of jobs and livelihoods in Scotland and across the UK."SNP MSP George Adam said:ldquoRichard Leonard has today confirmed that Scottish Labour is pro-Brexit ndash something that will utterly dismay many of its own supporters.ldquoThe clock is ticking on Brexit and we desperately need parties to work together against Theresa Mayrsquos bad deal and against no-deal. ldquoBut almost as soon as Labour say they could support a second referendum, Richard Leonard says it would be better for Brexit to go ahead.ldquoThat puts Labour completely at odds with the Scottish people ndash and it makes their apparent embrace of a second referendum look cynical in the extreme.ldquoItrsquos time for all parties to throw their weight behind a public vote, with Remain on the ballot, and put an end to this Brexit mess.Tory MSP Adam Tomkins added:ldquoEven Richard Leonard is now admitting the utter shambles his party have gotten themselves into over Brexit.ldquoAllowing a second EU referendum sets a dangerous precedent, and as he admits himself, it could lead to a second independence referendum.ldquoIt just goes to show once again how weak Labour are on the Union ndash they are willing to sell it out for political expediency.ldquoOnly the Scottish Conservatives are willing and able to stand up to the SNP and their plans to rip Scotland out of the UK.Scottish LibDem leader Willie Rennie condemned Mr Leonards red Brexit.He said: "Brexit would be bad for the economy and public services whether you paint it blue or red."Like Jeremy Corbyn, Richard Leonard has been reluctantly manoeuvred towards a Peoplersquos Vote but itrsquos disappointing that they are still not ruling out a Labour led Brexit.ldquoAnyone in the Labour party disappointed by the cynical triangulation of the Labour leadership should know that Scottish Liberal Democrats story: Mr Corbyn saidTheresa Mays Brexit deal gets through Parliament "there must be a confirmatory public vote".:Theresa May offers MPs Article  delay voteThe sht in policy, which would see voters asked to decide between a deal and remaining in the EU, won plaudits from Remain-supporting MPs but led to warnings of electoral disaster in some of Labours heartlands.The move also led to a spat between shadow cabinet ministers and anonymous party sources over the details of the pledge.Speaking in the Commons, Mr Corbyn said: "The Prime Ministers botched deal provides no certainty or guarantees for the future and was comprehensively rejected by this House."We cannot risk our countrys industry and peoples livelihoods and soit somehow does pass in some form at a later stage, we believe there must be a confirmatory public vote to seepeople feel it is what they voted for."Labour has said it will either support a motion calling for a referendum or table one itself.Labour MP John Mann said the move would be "catastrophic to Labour in the Midlands and the north".:Richard Leonard defies majority of Scots to back Brexit over second referendumThe Bassetlaw MP, who voted to leave the EU, told BBC Radio s Today: "Voters wont have it. story: First up this week was Jeremy Corbyn, who on Monday performed a humiliating U-turn on a Peoplersquos Vote.It is not dficult to see why the Labour leader decided, against his own instincts, to back the option.A poll, which asked people their voting preferences were Westminsterrsquos newly-formed centrist group a fully-fledged party, produced some alarming numbers for the Labour leader.It put the Tories on  per cent, a not insubstantial  points ahead of Labour on  with TIG on  and the Liberal Democrats on six.ButTIG and the Lib Dems were to merge at some point ndash as some hope - then on these numbers, the combined force would put Labour into third place. However, the Scotrsquos defiance could cost him his job as Scottish Secretary David Mundellrsquos parliamentary private secretary.The focus will quickly turn to mid-March when MPs are set to have not one, not two but three votes respectively on the PMrsquos new-look plan, a no-deal and extending Article .While Mrs May insists progress is being made, the UK-EU talks seem as far away from a resolution as ever the assumption at Westminster is whatever the PM s with on March  will not be enough.She was coy yesterday about how she and her Government would vote on the second vote on no-deal. Rightly so, as by then it could be Brexiteer ministers and not Remainers threatening resignation.Then will come the crunch third vote on extension. In such circumstances this will pass. But the key question will be: how long will be the delay Mrs May wants it ldquoas short as possible but MPs could successfully amend the motion to extend Article  for months.Whatever timeline MPs agree, there is then the little matter of getting the EU to endorse it.By then, Brussels will have the UK over a barrel becauseit were not to agree, then there would be nothing to stop the country crashing out of the bloc without a deal two weeks later.Then, of course, the Brexit monster might have yet another twist to torment us with.Asked what would happenMPs voted against all three options, the PMrsquo spokesman paused and said: ldquoThat would be quite contradictory and an unexpected thing to happen.But as we know in this never-ending psychodrama, anything can happen.

title: outlander-boost-for-scotlands-heritage-sites
story: The historic sites manned by the staff of Historic Environment Scotlandhave reported an increase in footfall to ,, people in , a five per cent increase on .The Amazon Prime series Outlander, the time-travel historical drama based on the best selling books by Diana Gabaldon, is shot at ious locations, including Doune Castle, Craigmillar Castle, Blackness Castle, Linlithgow Castle and Aberdour Castle: all have experienced record years.The most-visited staffed site was Edinburgh Castle with ,, visitors, a figure which is a rise of % on the previous year.Stirling Castle was the second-top visited site with , visitors, up %, followed by , visitors to Urquhart Castle.This is the first time Urquhart Castle has welcomed over , visitors in a single year, and represents a rise of % in visitors.Blackness Castle reaching , visitors for the first time ndash an increase of % from the previous year.The th century fortress is the setting for the Fort William headquarters of ldquoBlack Jack Randall in the series, while Doune Castle is the location for the fictional Castle Leoch in the series.Outlander premiered in , and much of its filming is done in Scotland, on location at historic sites, including the Old Town of Edinburgh, as well as purpose-built studios in Cumbernauld.The show, which stars Sam Heughan as Jamie Fraser and Caitriona Balfe as Claire Randall in its lead roles, has been a success for its producers Starz: they have agreed to make fth and sixth seasons.HES also had a record number of memberships in  which peaked at over , ndash up from % in .In total,  of the top  visited sites run by the HES registered record attendances.Sites staffed by the HES, they reported, generated poundm of local tourism expenditure in  ndash up poundm from  - and supported more than , full time equivalent jobs.Stephen Duncan, its director for commercial and tourism, said: ldquo was another fantastic year for Scotlandrsquos heritage sites, with visitor numbers continuing to grow.ldquoAs well as the lsquoOutlander effectrsquo bringing international visitors to Scotland to explore its rich history, we have also seen an increase in the number of Scots visiting heritage sites as evidenced in our highest ever membership figure.ldquoWith Scotland being used as a filming location for productions such as Outlaw King and Mary Queen of Scots, we hope visitors will continue to be inspired to explore the history of the sites they see on the big screen.Some of the HES sites were boosted by having the Lego exhibition, Brick Wonders, at their location: notably Glasgow Cathedral, Aberdour Castle, Arbroath Abbey and Stirling Castle.HES added that bad weather, which was dubbed the Beast from the East, affected sites at the beginning of , but overall there had been a steady increase in footfall.HES looks after  heritage sites in total, including  staffed Historic Scotland sites.Mr Duncan added: ldquoThese incredible figures show the importance that the historic environment has on local communities with the vast majority of economic growth generated by the increase in high-spending international visitors.ldquoFrom abbeys in the Borders to Norse settlements in Shetland, the appeal of Scotlandrsquos cultural heritage reaches far and wide and is there to be enjoyed by all.HES has made some investments in some of the sites.This includes a pound, investment project at Edinburgh Castle.He added: ldquoAnother commitment was to reach new audiences, particularly with the Year of Young People.ldquoWe launched Knight at the Castle, the first after-hours event at Edinburgh Castle targeting young people, and our touring LEGO exhibitions were a huge success across our regional sites with Aberdour Castle seeing a % increase in visitors from the previous year.Fiona Hyslop, the culture secretary, said: ldquoI would like to thank all those who contribute to caring for our precious and unique heritage.ldquoScotlandrsquos historic environment is a catalyst for economic growth ndash driving tourism, regeneration and sustainable development, and fuelling improvements.ldquoI am delighted Historic Environment Scotland has seen an increase in visitors and memberships.The top ten attractions according to HES are: Edinburgh Castle, Stirling Castle, Urquhart Castle, Glasgow Cathedral, Doune Castle, Skara Brae , Linlithgow Palace, St Andrewrsquos Castle. Fort George and Iona Abbey.

title: crossing borders with your dog after brexit
story: A. The answer to this all depends on whether we leave the EU with or without a deal and when you want to travel.Pet passports wont be valid with a no deal BrexitAt the minute, you are supposed to have a pet passport for your dogtheyrsquore travelling from the UK to the EU and vice versa, although it is my understanding that there are no checks on pets crossing the Republic or Ireland and Northern Ireland border at the minute. Pet passports list the dferent treatments your pet has had and ensures they are microchipped and up to date with their rabies vaccine.Read more: JD Wetherspoon favours more UK products as Brexit moves closerThe passport means your pooch wont have to go into quarantine on arrival.If the UK leaves without a deal, then the rules will change and pet passports issued in the UK would no longer be valid.In this case, pet owners would need to get a health certicate - and the bad news is, this will take at least four months. Your dog will need a rabies vaccine with blood samplestaken  days after the jab. title: embroidery exhibition at heritage centre
story: The Garioch Heritage Centre in Inverurie will host the Embroiderer#s Guild Lest We Forget embroidery exhibition next week.The free exhibition will run at the centre from Tuesday, February  to Tuesday, March .In  the Guild in conjunction with SSAFAinvited its members to take part in the commemoration of the ending of WW a  years previously by producing one heart.The plan being that each heart would be included in at least one exhibition, ideally, as near to their home location.Thus making unique and thoughtful exhibitions to fulfil the hope of a generation not to be forgotten.Using cloth, thread and textile each heart interprets a unique story of comradeship, bravery, victory or setback told by those ing from the Great War or in their heartfelt letters to those back home.The hearts illustrate to a new generation the men and the animals that accompanied them the unorms worn and medals won the regiments that fought together and the family members fondly remembered the songs that kept their spirits high and the words they wrote to those back home. This is a one-off, not to be missed, opportunity to view the  Scottish Hearts in the North East of Scotland. title: james going for gold in gordon
story: The Liberal Democrats have selected their next candidate to be in the running for Gordon#s MP seat.The party has chosen James Oates, the nephew of long-serving former Gordon MP Malcolm Bruce.After graduating from Aberdeen University  years ago, he became a campaigner for human rights in Central and Eastern Europe.Multi-lingual, he later worked in the region for large investment firms such as JP Morgan, Robert Fleming and UBS, and for the past ten years he has been working with technology businesses in Tallinn, Estonia and building investment across the region.Commenting Mr Oates said: “I’m running to be Gordon’s MP because our country needs and wants to change. “It’s time to bring new energy, after the negativity of the past four years. It’s time for us to look the prosperity of the future and let go of the failed politics of the past.“It’s time for a new commitment to make sure that the opportunities in Gordon and in all of Scotland are recognised by the whole of the United Kingdom. Our contributions are not appreciated and our needs have been ignored for far too long.”He added: “I will not be one of those MPs that sits in London ignoring the people who put him there in the first place.“If I learned anything from Malcolm, it’s that cooperation, effective representation and respect for our communities are the most important traits I could have. My door will always be open.“I will bring Gordon and the needs of the Northeast to the Government, not the other way around.“It’s time our voices were heard again.” Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

story: Career changers can now apply for a five-figure sum to support them while training to fill high-demand teaching roles in STEMsubjects.The move has been welcomed by Aberdeenshire East MSP Gillian Martin, a former college lecturer, who has previously backed encouraging more girls and women to take STEM subjects.A total of  bursaries are available in academic year   at a total cost of £ million - with Home Economics included for the first time.Applicants will be able to apply for a bursary of £,.Other STEM subjects in demand are Physics, Chemistry, Maths, Technical Education and Computing Science.Applications for bursaries have opened todayfor postgraduate teacher training courses beginning in August .Commenting, Gillian Martin MSP said: “This is a brilliant investment by the Scottish Government to help encourage more people to train in STEM subjects.“The development of skills in these subject areas will be vital for our future economy and will help to inspire the next generation of the Scottish workforce.“Bursaries like these will help to provide financial help and make it easier for people to make exciting career changes which will have an impact on pupils in the years ahead.”Skills Development Scotland Education Programme Lead Ken Edwards said: “The support offered by the STEM Bursary gives career changers the security to make the move from existing employment into teaching.“This will contribute to getting the right skills balance in the teaching workforce and in supporting young people to be engaged and enthused in their STEM learning.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.buchanobserver webimage ..! title: partnership for dentist and foodbank
story: An Inverurie dentist has teamed up with a local foodbank in a bid to offer much-needed support.Inverurie Smile Care has become formal Community Partners of the Inverurie Foodbank Centre.The Inverurie Foodbank Centre is part of Aberdeenshire North Foodbank, which has other food distribution centres in Ellon, Peterhead and Huntly as well as a central warehouse just outside Inverurie.The Foodbank Centre has been running in the town since .In  the Inverurie Foodbank Distribution Centre fulfilled  food parcel vouchers, providing food for the equivalent of  adults and  children - an  percent increase from .Commenting Debbie Rennie, Foodbank manager, said: “It is clear through their support of us since  and through recent discussions with them that they understand the need for the work that we are doing in the community and it is fantastic that they are supporting us with regular donations.“As much as we are worried about growing numbers of people needing emergency food parcels, what is positive about all of our Foodbank Centres, including Inverurie, is that local communities are coming together to meet local need through donating food, like Inverurie Smile Care have committed to doing, donating services, and the work of the foodbanks are predominantly done by local volunteers, which is so valuable.”Mohammed Khan, group marketing manager at Inverurie Smile Care added: “Be it regular foodbank donations, or sponsoring the Inverurie Academy Football teams, Smile Care are proud to be involved with the town of Inverurie: such engagement being a major, contributing factor to our award as ‘Scotland’s Best NHS Dental Practice’ at the Dentistry Scotland Awards .”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: Caithness to get firts vegan BB
story: A BED and breakfast with a dference is to be launched in Caithness next month.Barbara and Peter Gray, who live in Berriedale, will be opening what is thought to be the first vegan BB in the far north and the venture is already attracting interest online from people throughout the UK.The couple moved to Caithness in September after purchasing a property in the village.They come from Derbyshire but spent some time in Lincolnshire before moving to Golspie and then to Caithness.They say they both like the Highlands and wanted to set up a vegan bed and breakfast here.Barbara explained: ldquoWe saw the property at The Braes in Berriedale was up for sale last summer, put in an offer and it was accepted.ldquoAt present, we have a king size double en suite room but would hope to expand and have two to three rooms later.ldquoAs far as I know we are the only vegan BB in Caithness. I think the nearest one to us may be in Aviemore.ldquoFor a long time we have wanted to provide luxury accommodation and cooking for vegans but we will also show people how to cook vegan meals and may do workshops on an ad hoc basis as well as hosting special s for events such as Valentines Day and Burns Nights.ldquoWe will be open for business in March but are already getting interest online from people in the UK and hope eventually to generate interest in Europe and the USA.Asked what would happensomeone who is not a vegan wanted to stay at the BB, she replied: ldquoThey would have to take vegan food as we do not have animal products on the premises.ldquoWe live a vegan lestyle and would prefer vegans to stay here but they donrsquot have to be vegans.Her husband Peter helps run the business but is also a writer.He has been writing for many years but in  started work on a series of crime fiction books whose main character is Detective Inspector James Avalon. The police officer is based in Inverness but travels throughout the Highlands.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Delay to Wick 20 mph speed limit plans
story: THE brakes have been put on plans to introduce a  mph speed limit on the majority of roads in Wick.The proposal was mooted by Highland Council as a way to improve road safety and encourage walking and cycling.However, Wick members of the Caithness committee this week described the scheme as "a blunt instrument" and said other measures to reduce speed would be more effective. They also felt the consultation period should be extended by three weeks to allow the public more time to respond to the plan.Speaking at the meeting in Wick Town Hall on Wednesday, Councillor Nicola Sinclair said she was "very much in favour" of improving road safety but was concerned about the scale of the  mph limit and claimed there should be a longer period of consultation."The consultation took place over the Christmas period and I dont think people got enough opportunity to get their views heard," she said.Full report in Fridayrsquos John OrsquoGroat Journal.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Prince Harry set to attend Mey games
story: THE Mey Highland Games is going to ldquoput Caithness in the global spotlight, according to its organiser Captain Richard Otley, after Prince Harry announced he would attend the event this year.Rumours were re last year that Harry and his we Meghan would attend the special event which included para-athletes for the first time but when the royal retinue appeared at pm there was no sign of the couple.Capt Otley believes that the information released over the weekend to the media about Prince Harryrsquos attendance may have come from Buckingham Palace itself. title: Roadworks to be carried out at four Caithness locations
story: ROAD improvements costing pound, are to be carried out at four Caithness locations, starting next week.The work, to be carried out by Bear Scotland, will begin at Hempriggs on the A on Monday and will conclude at Thrumster in April.A spokeswoman for the company said: "We have a pound, programme of road improvements planned across four locations in the Caithness area on the A and A in March and April."Starting on Monday, surfacing improvements will first take place on the A at Hempriggs for  days to address the worn-out road surface and localised rutted sections. Works will then move to the A south of Georgemas for  days from Monday, March , to carry out surfacing improvements on the route."A three-day patching project will then take place on the A Berriedale south brae which will address defects in the road surface, followed by an eight-day surfacing project for a stretch of the A at Thrumster in April."The spokeswoman said the projects will take place during the day, from am to pm, with no work planned at weekends to keep disruption to a minimum. A mph convoy system will be in place during working hours to escort traffic past the works areas at each location."Teams will do all they can to complete the projects as quickly and safely as possible. However, we encourage people to plan their journeys in advance by checking the Traffic Scotland website for up to date journey information," the spokeswoman added.Wick and east Caithness Highland councillor, Raymond Bremner, has been pressing for the road improvements on that section of the A and is "absolutely delighted" they are going ahead."The northbound side of the road has been in a deteriorating state of repair for some time and it certainly looked as though we were needing more than a pothole repair approach," he said. "I reviewed the road with an engineer in the spring of last year. As a result, and after a lot of discussion between the agencies, Bear and Transport Scotland, Irsquom delighted the remedial works are about to start."Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Wick Francis Street Club placed in liquidation
story: WICKS Francis Street Club has been placed in liquidation, it was confirmed on Thursday.According to provisional liquidator Iain Fraser, a partner with FRP Advisory, the decision was made following a decline in membership, rising costs and unsustainable cash-flow problems. The club ndash founded in the s as a British Legion ndash has now closed and six staff have been made redundant.Mr Fraser said: "The Francis Street Club has been a landmark social, entertainment and sports venue in Caithness for nearly  years. Sadly, the club has been suffering severe financial problems and liquidation was the only option available to the committee."We are working closely with the relevant agencies, including the Redundancy Payments Office, to ensure the staff receive as much support as possible. We are now offering the assets of the business for sale, including the building, fixtures and fittings, and would urge interested parties to contact our Aberdeen office as soon as possible on   ."The Francis Street Club started was a long-established social, entertainment and sporting venue which attracted some well-known names through its doors, including former world snooker champion Stephen Hendry who staged an exhibition match there.It served as a social club and ran both football and darts teams, both well supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.The premises closed last month. At the time, a statement issued by the club said: "It was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , ."A note subsequently posted on the door read: "We have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course."Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: accessibility top of the agenda for northlink
story: Changes are being made by NorthLink Ferries to make their services more accessible to all.On board information workshops and the introduction of new website software are the latest efforts being made by the company to improve services for those with additional support needs.The ferry operator implemented its new Recite Me accessibility tool on its website, this month, to make it more suitable to folk#s needs. The new software — which can be used on desktops and mobile browsers — allows website visitors to customise what they see and hear, from changing the contrast settings, language, font size and more.In the UK, there are estimated to be . million people with a learning disability and . million people who have English as a second language. ‘Recite Me’ has the ability to translate the NorthLink Ferries website into more than  languages — including Scots Gaelic . It can also translate text-to-speech to help visually impaired users and focus screen areas for those with dyslexia.On Monday, February , teams on board MV Hamnavoe hosted an Access Panel Orkney session, where staff were provided with disability awareness training. During the two-hour session, staff were able to experience what it’s like to have a disability by wearing glasses that simulated blindness, used wheelchairs and crutches and had their hearing dampened.Carolyn Grfiths of Access Panel Orkney said: “The aim of our session was to let staff experience disabilities first-hand so they can empathise with passengers’ needs.#All of us running the training have a disability so we were able to provide first-hand examples of what accessible travel is like for us. We were delighted to be welcomed on board to provide this training and it’s great to see a company like Serco NorthLink Ferries take accessibility for passengers seriously.”The MV Hjaltland will also host a Making Connections workshop today, Friday, February . The workshop will look at how passengers navigate potential barriers when changing from one mode of transport to another. Making Connections brings disabled people together with transport operators to discuss, address and plan how travel connections can be made easier.Seumas Campbell, customer service director at NorthLink Ferries, said: “Catering for passengers with ying degrees of disability is an important part of our service provision. Whether they are using our website to book their journey, making a connection from other forms of public transport or coming on board one of our vessels, we believe that passengers should experience a service that caters to all their needs.“The new website software will allow visitors to customise what they see and hear and as more and more visitors from around the world choose NorthLink Ferries to travel to the Northern Isles, ‘Recite Me’ is a great tool to help them plan and book their journey.“Our workshops are also a great way in training our staff on how they can best help and understand passengers’ needs. title: alfred takes to the water in vietnam
story: PENTLAND Ferries and Strategic Marine Vietnam have announced the successful launch of the new vessel Alfred.At pm Vietnam time on Friday, well-wishers, invited guests, shipyard workers and Pentland Ferries team members lined the slipway as the completed hull of the ship rolled down the slipway and into the warm waters of where the vessel was built, Vung Tau, Vietnam.Since the keel was laid, approximately , tonnes of steel hull and aluminium superstructure have been welded together in a large workshop to create the flagship vessel for Pentland Ferries operations, named after Pentland Ferries managing director Andrew Banks# father Alfred Banks.The ship will carry  passengers and up to twelve lorries combined with  cars, or  cars in total.The final fit out of the interior will take place prior to a complete series of sea trials in Vietnam before Pentland Ferries crew sail Alfred back to home base in St Margaret#s Hope.Joseph Azran Alemberg SMV chief operating officer said: “Today’s a big day for Strategic Marine Vietnam and a proud moment for everyone that contributed to the vessel build. title: in the footsteps of dr john rae
story: Next month will see a group of intrepid adventurers undertake a -mile mission in the Canadian Arctic, retracing the footsteps of one of Orkney#s most renowned, yet also overlooked, sons — Dr John Rae.The Arctic Return expedition will see a four-man team set off from Naujaat — also known as Repulse Bay — in late March, aiming to retrace the footsteps made by the surgeon, explorer and surveyor in .It was on that expedition that the explorer finally discovered an open channel to the east of King William Island in the high arctic. Known today as Rae Strait, it was the missing link in what would become the first navigable Northwest Passage.He also reported back on the ill-fated Franklin expedition, reported evidence of cannibalism — findings which were effectively rejected by the then establishment, and which led to Rae#s achievements being almost completely ignored.The modern-day team, who hope to raise further awareness of these achievements, will be led by Scottish-born and Canada-based expedition leader David Reid, with Scotland also represented by Broxburn-based former Royal Marine Richard Smith.The team will also include two Canadians — adventure film-maker Gerry Tutte and adventurer Frank Wolf.Over  years later and supported with modern-day kit from outdoor specialists Tiso, the explorers are hard at work preparing for the physical and mental challenge of hauling kg sledges for nine hours daily and for up to  consecutive days.Their route will cover undulating, windswept tundra, river valleys and sea ice during what can be the coldest time of year.The Arctic expedition will finish once the four explorers have finally reached Gjoa Haven on King William Island.Mr Smith said: #The Arctic Return expedition will be extremely tough but ultimately our aim is to raise awareness fo the exploits of John Rae and to help restore his rightful place as one of the greatest Scottish explorers in history. It is also our hope that this awareness will inspire the public to support fundraising efforts by the John Rae Society, to restore Rae#s birthplace at the Hall of Clestrain in Oprhir.The team have said any addition funds raised are to be used to produce a documentary film and book about the le and exploits of Rae, the expedition and the history communities, culture and wildle of the Arctic.The public will be able to track the team#s progress at their official website and through social media.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. The Orkney MSP has today, Tuesday, urged the Scottish Government to #pay heed to the realities of fuel poverty.#The figures, published by the Scottish Government, showed that the fuel poverty rate in Orkney was  per cent — compared to  per cent in the City of Edinburgh.“Fuel poverty levels are shameful Scotland-wide in this day and age,# said Mr McArthur.#However, these figures underline that rural and island communities are disproportionately badly affected.“I have consistently made the case for recognition of this alarming disparity, and I am glad that the Housing Minister has now agreed to look at options to recognise that ahead of Stage Two of the Fuel Poverty Bill.“Orkney and other rural and island communities urgently need targeted action to reduce the astronomical rates of fuel poverty and extreme fuel poverty. title: mcarthur welcomes fuel poverty re think
story: Orkney’s MSP, Liam McArthur has welcomed Scottish Government plans to ensure that its Fuel Poverty Bill recognises the higher costs faced by those living in remote rural and island areas.During the stage one debate in Parliament yesterday, Wednesday, the Housing Minister, Kevin Stewart indicated that he would bring forward amendments to the bill to include an ‘uplt’ to the minimum income standard for rural and island communities. Mr McArthur believes this reflects a change in approach by the government, after months of campaigning by the Orkney MSP and a range of organisations involved in tackling fuel poverty across the Highlands and Islands.During his remarks, Mr McArthur pointed out that when it comes to fuel poverty, rural and island areas are disproportionately affected, with Orkney having the highest proportion of households in fuel poverty and extreme fuel poverty anywhere in Scotland.Commenting after the debate, Mr McArthur said: “Fuel poverty blights communities across Scotland, but there is no doubt that it has a disproportionate impact on rural and island areas. Until recently, however, the Scottish Government appeared unwilling to recognise this fact or indeed the higher costs faced by those living in our rural and island communities.“Over recent months, working with a range of organisations with a wealth of experience and expertise in tackling fuel poverty, I have made the case for the Minister, Kevin Stewart to think again.  It was a case that the Local Government Committee was also persuaded to support.“I am delighted, therefore, that the Minister has had a change of heart and committed to bring forward amendments to his bill at stage two that better reflect the specic nature of fuel poverty in places like Orkney.  I look forward to seeing the detail of those amendments and will work with Mr Stewart, and local stakeholders in Orkney, to make sure we get this right.“Given the impact fuel poverty can have, not just on people’s quality of le but their physical and mental health, this bill has the potential to make a real dference.  For that to happen, it must be both effective and ambitious in eradicating fuel poverty from communities across the country.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
