title: Ambitious plan sets goals to end fuel poverty
story: PEOPLE across Ross-shire could benefit after the Scottish Government incorporated changes into its own draft legislation to ldquoend the scourge of fuel poverty.An earlier barrage of criticism claimed the Fuel Poverty Bill missed the target when it came to delivering for the ldquoworst affected areas.Fuel poverty is defined as when households spend  per cent or more of income on domestic fuel ndash reckoned to account for one in four homes in Scotland.The figure is understood to be signicantly higher across swathes of Ross-shire, hitting homes which are not on the gas grid and reliant on oil and low-income households.Minister for local government, housing and planning, Kevin Stewart, promised to include ldquoa rural, remote and island minimum income standard in poverty calculations as well as what he called ldquoa rural uplt.He was speaking at the first stage of a Holyrood debate of the Bill which aims to cut fuel-poor households to five per cent by  from the current national average of almost  per cent.The move was welcomed by rural housing associations and local councillors but Highlands Tory MSP Jamie Halcro Johnston vowed to maintain pressure on the government to deliver on what was promised.He said: "The minister announced that a new rural, remote and island minimum income standard will be included in their fuel poverty calculations alongside a rural uplt. We will be looking to strengthen the Bill as it progresses through the Scottish Parliament and ensuring that the Scottish Governmentrsquos pledges are met."Before Wednesdayrsquos debate Mr Stewart said: ldquoWithin this ground-breaking legislation, not only are we one of the few countries in the world to define fuel poverty, we are also setting a goal towards eradicating it.ldquoBy changing the definition of fuel poverty so itrsquos more closely aligned to relative income poverty and taking steps to ensure it works for remote rural and island communities, we are ensuring our support is focussed on those who need it most."He added: "In this day and age, it is unacceptable that any Scottish household should have to choose between having the heating on and cooking their dinner.Councillor Ian Cockburn, who represents the Wester Ross, Strathpeffer and Lochalsh welcomed the Bill as "something has to be done about fuel poverty" while arguing it is also time to rethink infrastructure like the national grid."It is ambitious but has to be tried to get fuel poverty down in rural areas. We are one of the most energy rich countries in the world so we should be able to get something done. Too many people take it as just being part of the landscape up here so we need to change that thinking as well to get people the assistance that they need."Scotland should not be in this state. But you have to look back, the National Grid was set up at the end of the war, the Highlands is considered off-grid despite supplying much of the rest of the country through hydro and wind power. It is time for a rethink."Calum Macaulay, chief executive of Invergordon-based Albyn Housing Society, said: ldquoWe welcome this development in the Scottish Governmentrsquos approach to addressing fuel poverty in rural areas. The push to include minimum income standards feels like a signicant step forwards. This is something that the Rural and Islands Housing Association Forum has been promoting for quite some time."This has included research undertaken with the support of Highlands and Islands Enterprise and others into minimum income standards in rural communities. The results of this highlighted the pressures of lower average household incomes and higher average fuel costs across the northern parts of Scotland."What do you think  Share your views by emailing newsdesk@spp-groupWednesday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Black Isle authors French connection helps ensure nothing is lost in translation
story: Vee Walkers Major Toms War, partly set in France during WWI, is now fittingly being translated into French for a new edition of the book.Such has been the response to the novel that the Black Isle author has already been on a book tour and visited France on the back of it. The annual Franco-Scottish Society Alexander Gray Fund Lecture in Inverness on Friday promises to be alight-hearted bilingual talk from Ms Walker and her "long-suffering" Parisian translator Richard Kausch.Major Tomrsquos War is a moving novel set in France during the First World War, in part in the grim lsquozones occupeacuteesrsquo of northern France.Its characters are real people ndash and both author and translator have had to enter the minds of the novelrsquos key protagonists.The novel is published in English by Kashi House in London and the French edition should follow late this year or early in .Veeand Richard will be touring four of the regional Franco-Scottish Societies of Scotland this month.The groups exist to foster French language and culture in Scotland and meet monthly for French conversation or a lecture.Those who come along are welcome to join or to attend as a non-member. They are suitable for Higher Advanced Higher French pupils and their teachers.Vee confesses that as a French-speaking author she has not madeher translatorsle any easier: "Most translators produce a translation and the author would not have a clue about whether or not it is representative or accurate."My first degree was in French and although I am not a native speaker, I have had an opinion on nuance and vocabulary right the way through."Richard is currently revising the French text a second time to address the changes requested by my English publishers for the First Edition. He has the patience of a saint and I donrsquot know what I would have done without him!"Wersquore both looking forward to meeting audiences in Aberdeen, Edinburgh, Glasgow and Inverness on our tour around Scotland very much."Vee and Richardrsquos final tour slot is in Inverness on Friday, February  at the Glen Mhor Hotel,  Ness Bank, Invernessat .pm.Thelecture is free and will be followed by a French meal atpm. Theres a fixed menu.Reservations can be booked on   for lecture and or meal. Themeal is pound to members andpound to non-members.Wednesday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Call for flexibility over closure of Rosemarkie toilets
story: FEARS are intensying over the future of public toilets in Rosemarkie after Highland Council revealed that it would only keep them open until the end of March.The th hour news appears to fly in the face of assurances given to local community leaders at a meeting last November and has sparked a petition that has already got more than  signatures from worried locals calling for the council to keep the facility open.It had been hoped a charitable trust could be set up to take over the running of the facility, a process anticipated to take months, but time for that is running out and in the meantime it is feared harm could be done to the villagersquos appeal as a visitor destination.The well-loved and well-respected Groam House Museum could be impacted as well, with staff and visitors both needing to use the public convenience as there are no facilities on the premises.A council spokeswoman said: ldquoA draft temporary lease is being drawn up to enable the planned Community Development Trust to be taken forward. If the facility is not taken on by the community then it will close on March as per report to the Highland Council [on] October .ldquoNo survey will be undertaken, the facility will transfer in lsquoas seen, as isrsquo condition, the facilities will transfer in their current operational condition. The position of toilets remaining open whilst negotiations are ongoing is for this financial year only. There is no budget to retain facilities... which is why we want to get the leases sorted out before the end of March.Despite that the director of the Groam House Museum Doug Maclean, who recently attended a meeting of the community council where the future of the toilets was on the agenda remains hopeful.ldquoWe are confident that by some means or other, through a charitable trust taking over the running of the toilets and the good services of the local people, we will be able to keep the toilets open, he said.However, Mr Maclean was in no doubt about how serious an effect the closure would have on Rosemarkie as well as Groam House Museum.ldquoFrom the museumrsquos point of view it is absolutely vital for our existence. We have groups of school children that come here and of course children need to go to the toilet, he said.ldquoWe also have groups of mainly elderly American tourists and they are not in a position to make their way to the beach cafeacute. And we would lose both those groups without the toilets which put the museum in jeopardy.Black Isle ward councillor Gordon Adam said: ldquoI am in discussions with the council over the time limit of March , my view is that the council needs to be flexible. Savings have to be made, but sticking rigidly to a timetable leaves little time to form development groups.Wednesday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Climate action call comes to Inverness streets
story: CLIMATE change activists from the Black Isle and Inverness have shown their solidarity for school pupils across the world after the youngsters held a lsquostrikersquo to flag up ecological concerns.New group Extinction Rebellion Highlands and Islands held a stall in Inverness High Streetlast Saturday, asking passers-by to sign a petition calling for urgent action by Highland Council to do its bit to tackle the threat, amid growing worries that the planetrsquos global warming is nearing an irreversible tipping point.Organised by Black Isle activist Anne Thomas, who is also involved with Transition Black Isle, the stall attracted  signatures in the space of  minutes.The youth strike, which included Highland participants, was sparked by Swedish teenager Greta Thunberg who spoke at the last major UN Climate Change summit saying adults were not doing enough and time was running out.ldquoLots of people had been impressed by the stand the kids had taken and were keen to show their support, said Ms Thomas. ldquoThey agreed that government at all levels is not doing enough to stop dangerous levels of global warming and climate change.ldquoScientists say we have less than  years to prevent warming going over . degrees, so we need to take drastic measures now. We could be on the brink of a mass extinction like the one which wiped out the dinosaurs.ldquoThe petition asked that the Highland Council... reverse inconsistent policies and work alongside the media to communicate with residents.The petition also called on the local authority to pass a climate emergency motion to make the region carbon neutral by .Fiona Cormie who has just taken on the role of co-ordinator of the group, said they hoped to add ldquosignicantly to its number of petition signatories in the coming weeks and present them to the council.Wednesday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Conon Bridge pupils injury sparks community discussion
story: AN accident at a Ross-shire school which left a child with a badly broken leg will be discussed by Conon Bridge Community Council.Max McPhee was five when a large stone fell from a boundary wall at Ben Wyvis Primary School in May , crushing his leg.After months of treatment the youngster, now seven, has been left with one leg cm shorter than the other. This week it emerged that the boy had won legal action against Highland Council.The local authority, whose former chief executive Steve Barron had to apologise to parents for a series of faults with the building after its completion, had denied liability throughout the civil action.But it backed down when the boyrsquos solicitor Digby Brown proved it knew of an earlier debris fall one year before Max was injured.Secretary of Conon Bridge Community Council John Bruce said the matter will be on their agenda at their meeting next Wednesday.At the time of Maxrsquos accident, the chairwoman of the community council, Fiona MacKintosh, said there had been a catalogue of repairs to the pound million school since it opened in  including the closure of the main games hall.After the settlement was announced Maxrsquos mum Louiseaccused the council of acting shamefully over her sonrsquos injury. She said: ldquoItrsquos shocking that Highland Council didnrsquot have the decency to hold their hands up and just help a little boy who was hurt by their own failings.A Highland Council spokeswoman said: ldquoIt is the councilrsquos policy not to comment on insurance claims.Wednesday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Dingwall story circle is first of many
story: A HIGHLAND councillor hopes that a new story circle which uses books to tackle prejudice and intolerance will be the first of many across Scotland ndash following its successful arrival in Dingwall.Heartstone, which has been based in Dingwall for the past  years and works to build understanding across cultures and nationalities, has enjoyed success where in the UK with exhibitions in the likes of London and Edinburgh.And they brought the message lsquohomersquo last week with a new story circle in Dingwall library, reading the fantasy tale The Heartstone Odyssey.The novel is aimed at nine to -year-olds and sees the fantasy aspects interwoven with deeper issues such as prejudice and intolerance.The story circle was opened by John West from High Le Highland along with Highland councillor Andrew Jarvie and Sita Kumari, the director of Heartstone.Cllr Jarvie said working on the project had been a privilege, adding: ldquoI really do hope that this is the start of many of these story circles and that we can work with the Scottish Government to give this home grown organisation the  it deserves across Scotland.The story circle was lead by Ms Kumari who took on the role of storyteller and dancer as she brought to le the heroine of the story, Chandra.Ms Kumari, said: ldquoThis book deals with the issues through the imagination, without lecturing or preaching, changing hearts and minds to see beyond stereotypes and prejudice and to recognise a common humanity.She was inspired to create the organisation when she was first told the story over  years ago.ldquoIt was first told to me as an oral story on a three-day train journey from Mumbai to Chennai in the rsquos from which everything has followed, she explained. ldquoIt was a le-changing experience leading to the formation of Heartstone.Carmen Garcia-Pagan, library supervisor at Dingwall Library, said the library were delighted to be involved in the launch: ldquoThe Heartstone Odyssey is a thought-provoking tale which tackles some powerful issues.Wednesday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Family remember happy and friendly teenager after tragic accident near Inverness
story: The family of a teenager killed in a road traffic collision at Dochgarroch has spoken about their "happy-go-lucky boy who was always happy and friendly".Policehave confirmed that the -year-old who died as a result of the two-vehicle collision at around .pm on Sunday night was Samuel Foster, of Lochend near Inverness.The family said: ldquoSamuel, our darling boy, was incredibly popular and had a huge circle of friends. He attended Millburn Academy before moving to Inverness College two years ago to study engineering."He also worked at the bakery at Marks and Spencer for two years and loved his motocross biking and cars.ldquoSamuel was a happy-go-lucky boy who was always happy and friendly.ldquoSamuel was the youngest of four siblings and words canrsquot express how much he will be missed by his parents Heather and Lenny, his brother David and twin sisters Samantha and Kirsty, his nephew Reuben and niece Georgie.ldquoWe would like to thank the incredible number of people who have sent us messages of sympathy ndash your kind words mean so much and are a reminder of just how popular and well-loved Samuel was."We hope he will always be remembered this way.Wednesday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Funding blow to Ross shire alcohol support service
story: ALCOHOLISM support in Ross-shire has been dealt a blow after a group that helps people fight addiction announced its closure ndash amid funding cuts and increasing red tape.The board of Alcohol Counselling Services Ross and Sutherland , which has been supporting people in the region for more than  years, has ldquosadly and regretfully decided that the service will close from April .News of the closure has been greeted with dismay by recovering addicts, one of whom, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that without the service their ldquooutcome could have been very dferent.Explaining the reasons for the closure, the servicersquos co-ordinator, Chris Cochrane, said: ldquoThis decision has not been taken lightly. There are many reasons why this course of action is necessary, the main one being the struggle to secure sufficient finances to run the organisation.About pound, to pound, is needed annually but Ms Cochrane said that the NHS is doing a review of third sector input, and can only confirm funding up to June.Without the support of the NHS, they will find it dficult to win the support of other funding bodies.The news will be a blow to the  service users currently on the books of ACSRS many of whom faced a personal battle before seeking help and then keeping on attending to receive the support on offer.However Ms Cochrane said they will do everything in their power to ensure their clients receive alternative assistance with their dependency. Around  people with alcohol dependency are referred to them each year.She said: ldquoThe board is actively pursuing alternative arrangements for our service users and volunteer counsellors who wish to continue their support or volunteering.ldquoACSRS has been indebted to many people over the years who have given their time and expertise freely as volunteers. Some have assisted in the management of the service as board members providing governance and support for staff and volunteers.ldquoOthers have given thousands of hours of their free time as trained volunteer counsellors. There are six counsellors and not all of them will be wanting to move on though some might seek paid employment.ldquoThe training for these counsellors was previously provided free. It now requires a source of additional funding.ldquoAs for other voluntary organisations, the burden of bureaucracy has increased without the corresponding increase in income, and the task of securing additional funding has become more challenging.ldquoACSRS is the only voluntary organisation within Ross-shire and Sutherland offering a free professional one-to-one counselling service for those affected by their own or a loved onersquos addiction. Our work complements the work done by NHS Drug and Alcohol Recovery staff.ldquoWe would like to thank all those people for their extremely valuable contributions which made it possible for us to serve our community for over  years.Councillor Margaret Paterson, Dingwall and Seaforth, said: ldquoI know this group and this will be a dreadful loss as they give a tremendous service. It is quite distressing to hear this because they have given people with addiction and their families such help for so many years. Their volunteers have given such time and talent to help the vulnerable in society, butthey donrsquot have money then they just canrsquot do it. I hope that something can be done to continue their good work.Two service users who wished to remain anonymous praised ACSRS for the help they received. One said: ldquoI can honestly say that ACSRS played a major part in my recovery. If that help was not there when I needed it, the outcome could have been very dferent.The other said: ldquoHearing a voice that was willing to listen to me was a relief on one of the darkest days of my le.Wednesday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Highland Council investing extra in roads maintenance
story: Highland Council is hoping an additional pound. million for maintenance announced as part of this yearrsquos budget will make a ldquonoticeable dference across the region.The funding, approved as a priority area for the revenue budget, will be shared out across Highland with area committees able to decide how to prioritise it more locally.Chairman of the councilrsquos environment, development and infrastructure committee, Councillor Allan Henderson, said: ldquoWe have the most extensive network of roads in the UK and, added to this, we are faced with some of the most severe weather conditions in the Highlands.ldquoThe freeze-thaw conditions in particular cause immense damage to road surfaces and this is very evident in the past few weeks.ldquoRoad conditions are a high priority for local residents and this was very clear in our recent engagement with communities and local representatives.ldquoThe additional resource will, I hope, make a noticeable dference and can be allocated to the roads with the most urgent need of repairs, right across the Highlands.Area allocations based on road mileage and population are:Badenoch  Strathspey: pound, Caithness: pound,Inverness: pound, Lochaber: pound, Nairn: pound,Ross  Cromarty: pound,Isle of Skye: pound,Sutherland: pound,Wednesday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Invergordon ports plans put on public display
story: MORE than  members of the public took the opportunity to get a closer look at the Port of Cromarty Firthrsquos ambitious poundm expansion plans.The public information event in the port offices in Invergordon on Wednesday afternoon also allowed visitors to ask questions about the scheme. The port says the expansion is needed to maximise opportunities in the renewable energy sector and the cruise ship trade.Port marketing manager, Joanne Allday, said the response to the plans had been very encouraging.ldquoWe wanted to let people know what was happening, she said.ldquoIt was lovely to see so many people attending and taking an interest. There were lots of questions about how the project would progress, but people were very positive about it. They can see the benefits it can bring.Work has already begun on the quayside construction and is expected to run until March next year.The additional space will be used to assemble turbines for the Moray East Offshore Windfarm, but will also allow Invergordon, which is already Scotlandrsquos busiest cruise port, to accommodate the largest cruise ships currently being designed and built.This is the second quayside expansion at Invergordon in three years.Wednesday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Landmark anniversary for Ullapool arts hub
story: ONE of the countryrsquos smallest independent art schools is set to celebrate a major milestone by marking the st anniversary of its flagship course.Bridge House Art in Ullapool has been running its Portfolio Course since the late rsquos.In that time the school has built a growing reputation and has hosted students from as far afield as Lithuania, France, Switzerland, Spain and the USA.And on Sunday will celebrate the anniversary with its annual exhibition of portfolio course work ndash following an intensive four month training in the visual arts for  people from across the UK and mainland Europe.RESONANCE opens and will run daily from am to pm to March  at An Talla Solais Gallery, West Argyle Street, Ullapool and entry is free.It promises to be an eclectic mix of drawing, painting, printmaking, jewellery and illustration. Much of the work will be available for sale.Eleanor White, founder and principal tutor said: ldquoThe ethos behind all of our courses is to encourage everybody to learn to communicate visually and express a genuine response to the environment around us. I have been delighted with the way this yearrsquos students have responded to the challenge, this promises to be an excellent exhibition.Coming from a range of ages and backgrounds, the students have one thing in common ndash a shared desire to develop as artists. The -week course covers a range of disciplines including painting, printmaking, textiles and sculpture. Each inidual spends the second term developing a themed body of work and these will be on show at the exhibition.Kittie Jones, senior tutor and award-winning professional artist, said: ldquoI am always impressed by the dedication, hard work and motivation of the students on this course, many of them have moved up here to be part of the course and the results speak for themselves.Wednesday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Mystery oil tank artist adds a splash of colour to Invergordon
story: ITrsquoS a site steeped in local history and a lasting legacy to Invergordonrsquos nautical history.But the disused fuel tanks which stored the oil which powered some of the Royal Navyrsquos greatest warships during World War II has been a blight on the landscape of the Easter Ross port for generations.Recently, however, a graffiti artist has been hard at work beautying some of the relics, doing a lsquoBanksyrsquo with colourful images at the giant Seabank fuel tanks near the railway line, adding to lots of mural street art in the town already undertaken by the Invergordon Off The Wall group.Now the search is on to find the mystery painter who has already made a start on a canvas of over  massive tanks to choose from.Local woman Jacqueline Brown said she wasnrsquot sure exactly when the artwork was done: ldquoBut we would love to find out who is doing it.ldquoThe site really is out of bounds to the public but people go in and walk their dogs. I think I first saw the murals last year and they are quite stunning. Whoever is doing it is obviously very talented. Itrsquos a fascinating site. We know Invergordon became a naval town and was the base for the Home Fleet in World War I. These tanks were built for the supply of fuel to warships and they were in use until the mid-s.Mrs Brown said like many street artists, the person who carried out the work may wish to remain anonymous and even be fearful of prosecution.ldquoI just donrsquot know. But what they have done is quite beautul. I am sure we could find more projects for them in Invergordon including the town house which the community wants to take back into public ownership.A website documenting historical and derelict places in Scotland reveals the depot was built in conjunction with secret oil storage tanks a few miles away.It records the underground tanks were built to hold  million gallons of oil fuel and were built into a solid rock hill to protect it from bombs.On February ,  a Junkers  is reported to have carried out a solo attack on the tank farm, dropping two lb bombs damaging two tanks. But none of the bombs exploded although they cause a major spillage of oil.Mrs Brown said she understood there were plans to remove some tanks to build houses. She said: ldquoBut it takes time for these sites to be decontaminated from their former industrial uses.In , flats built in Joss Street had to be demolished because the site, which had been formerly used as a gas works, hadnrsquot been properly decontaminated.What do you think  Share your views by emailing us at newsdesk@spp-groupWednesday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: brexit richard leonard would rather have labour deal than second referendum
story: Sorry, were having problems with our video player at the moment, but are working to fix it as soon as we canWaiting for Video...SCOTTISH Labour leader Richard Leonard has said he#d rather have a Labour Brexit deal than a second EU referendum - but that he would still back Remaina second vote was held.Mr Leonard said thatLabour’s five point Brexit plan was not adopted by Theresa May in Westminster then there should be a second public vote on leaving the EU.But he admitted that a second EU referendum could also see an increase in demand for a another Scottish independence vote.Speaking after he addressed his group of MSPs, he said: “If we are not successful in amending the Theresa May deal then we feel we are left with no option than to back a public vote. “We have said we are looking for signicant changes to the deal that is on the table - a permanent Customs Union, close alignment with the Single Market, guarantees around the rights and protections people have as workers and consumers and environmental protections and collaboration with the EU around security and arrest warrants - and so my preference is for that deal.”However he saidLabour was unsuccessful he would back a second referendum but that it must include both Remain and “a credible Leave option” on the ballot.“I am worried about Labour voters who voted Leave. I would be concernedpeople who voted Leave felt abandoned by the Labour Party. But we are trying to steer a way through what is a very dficult situation created by Theresa May,” he said.“Our strategy has been to try and hold the country together. We have not got to that point [a second referendum] yet but my own position is that I would vote for Remain.” Mr Leonard said that he also backed the Yvette Cooper-Oliver Letwin amendment which will be debated in Westminster tomorrow which would remove a no deal and extend Article .But he refused to say whether Scottish Labour would stand candidates in the European Parliament elections in June,the UK was still in the EU at that time: SNP urge Richard Leonard to sayhe backs a second EU referendum©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: brexit second referendum takes a step closer to reality leader comment
story: A second Brexit referendum would need to ensure all sides of the debate were able to express their opinion.Labour has taken a long time to come round to the idea, but a week after a group of pro-Remain MPs quit the party to form the Independent Group, it has finally decided to push for a second Brexit referendum.Theresa May’s proposed deal is far from the vision that won the support of  per cent of voters in the  referendum and is even opposed by the most ardent of Brexiteers, people like Nigel Farage and Jacob Rees-Mogg.According to existing UK law, the only other alternative is a no-deal Brexit, which would quite clearly cause serious damage to the UK economy and should not be considered as an option by anyone with the UK’s national interests at heart.Labour is now set to back an amendment to rule out a no-deal and will also put forward its own Brexit plan for a “permanent and comprehensive customs union” and “close alignment with the single markets”.This may or may not be realistic – given the EU’s stance against a re-negotiation – but Jeremy Corbyn added that Labour would back “an amendment in favour of a public vote to prevent a damaging Tory Brexit being forced on the country”. David Lammy, a prominent Remain-supporting Labour MP, said Corbyn was “taking the first step to reunite our party by showing he is listening to our voters and members on this, the biggest issue of our time”.: Brexit: Labour to back second referendum in parliamentIt is often said that the EU referendum was held in an attempt to solve an internecine war within the Conservative party. Now, it seems, Labour’s internal troubles could bring about another one.Clearly, the chances of this actually happening will depend on the attitude of many Conservative MPs – and not just Remain ones. Labour’s decision could simply prompt Brexiteer MPs to drop their opposition to May’s deal, fearing the ‘will of the people’ is now pro-Remain.But,a second vote does come about, the big question will be the question. BrexitRef would undoubtedly be a isive affair and there would be a serious risk of a boycott by Brexiteers, which could cause potentially irreparable harm to democracy in this country.So considerable efforts would need to be made to try to bring Farage, Rees-Mogg and the like on board. And the question would have to be one that allowed all sides of this most tortuous debate to have their final – final – say on the matter.: Brexit: The Scotsman calls for second referendum – leader comment©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: richard leonard tony blair s middle ground is a right wing nightmare
story: The bedroom tax, rape clause and hostility to migrants show just how wrong Tony Blair was to say Labour had abandoned the #middle ground# of politics, writes Richard Leonard.Remember the bedroom tax  That pernicious Tory policy that encapsulated so much about what and who the Tories represent: seeing a housing crisis and punishing those who had the least to do with causing it and the most to lose from being forced to move out of their homes.Labour forced the SNP Government to scrap it in Scotland, after it initially refused to act. And we have called for it to do the same with the two-child cap on claims for tax credits and Universal Credit, and the rape clause that comes with it. Let’s call this what it is, a particularly abhorrent piece of Tory social engineering, which forces women to re-live the trauma of being raped as part of a claim for financial support for a child.These measures, as illustrative as they are, barely scratch the surface of the level of cuts to social security imposed by the Tories since  – and, of course, supported by the Liberal Democrats in the coalition government. Billions of pounds slashed from benefits and support programmes for the very people who most need our help: sick, disabled and unemployed people, and those who rely on extra support because they are not paid enough to live on. Cruel cuts underpinned by a cruel sanctions regime, so painfully and accurately portrayed in the film ‘I, Daniel Blake’, based partly on people’s experiences in Scotland.This is the brutal reality of austerity. A political choice to use the power of the state in one of the wealthiest countries in the world, not to make iniduals’ lives better and to improve society as a whole, but to tear people’s lives apart. And this is without even mentioning the tens of billions of pounds cut from our public services.: Tony Blair: Scotland would be independentnot for devolutionAnd it is before we have even begun to consider the Tories’ despicable hostile environment that targets migrants, conceived by Theresa May as Home Secretary and continued under her as Prime Minister. Remember those ad vans sent out by May’s Home Office with the nasty threat “Go home or face arrest”  Policies rooted in the worst instincts of the Tory Party, egged on by sections of the press whose front pages regularly scream about the threat posed by migration but never shout about the positive benefits it brings to our country, our culture and our way of le.But it is not some fanatical Tory clique in England that claims all of this is “necessary”, this is the Conservative Party right across the UK including here in Scotland. Ruth Davidson has proudly talked about how she backed Theresa May as leader, and how she “will back her in the future”. Scottish Secretary David Mundell and stand-in Scottish leader Jackson Carlaw line up foursquare behind the Prime Minister, even as her Brexit shambles goes from farce to horror.This is the Conservative Party that former Labour Prime Minister Tony Blair bizarrely said last week had claimed the “middle ground” of politics. If that is the middle ground, I shudder to think what would be right of centre.Scottish Labour has serious work to do, no one in our party is pretending otherwise and no one has ever claimed it is easy-going. We are rebuilding after years of decline and a series of electoral shocks, not least the  General Election when all but one of our  MPs were voted out, including the then leader Jim Murphy.Far from abandoning the mythical “middle ground” which, in truth, only pundits talk about, we are rebuilding on the basis of popular, common sense policies that focus on the real change that Scotland needs. An end to austerity and the cuts to social security and local services, and public ownership of our trains, buses, energy and Royal Mail, to put people before profit. We need Labour governments in Scotland and across the UK to put this into practice.Of course, it was gravely disappointing that just over a week ago a small group of Labour MPs chose to walk away, to join forces with former Tory MPs in a new Independent Group. In going, they have raised some important issues about Labour, not least the issue of antisemitism which we are determined to root out of our party and wider society. There is no place for antisemitism in the Labour Party.But they have also been clear that their disagreements range wider and are on matters of policy. In a magazine interview, one of the former Labour MPs has already criticised plans to bring the railways into public ownership and raise the top rate of tax. Another has suggested the group could replace the DUP in propping up the Tory Government. The first act of one of their former Tory colleagues was to declare that the coalition government, which ushered in austerity and led to record levels of poverty and homelessness, “did a marvellous job”.: Lesley Riddoch: Citizens’ Assemblies could help build a new ScotlandThese are very dferent ideas to the ones that proved so popular in the  election and which they were elected to Parliament on, so it is right that their constituents get the chance to ask them in by-elections what they now stand for. The group claims to represent a new, forward-looking “centre ground”. Butall it is going to offer is support for austerity, tax breaks for the rich and privatisation of public services, it will look very much like the failed politics of the past.No one yet knows what the political fall-out will be. But it will not deter Labour from our mission to bring the curtain down on this rotten Tory Government and so to see the back of the party of social security cuts, the two-child cap, austerity, homelessness, foodbanks and inequality. And it will not deter us from campaigning to win back people’s trust and so to win power again in the Scottish Parliament.We stand for something completely dferent. We don’t look at the housing crisis and see an opportunity to blame and punish the very people it affects the most. We won’t cut the lelines from our communities and our industries, we will invest in them, and we will build an economy and a society where everyone benefits, not just a wealthy few.©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: brexit theresa may caves to pressure offering mps chance to prevent no deal
story: Sorry, were having problems with our video player at the moment, but are working to fix it as soon as we canWaiting for Video...Theresa May has bowed to pressure from pro-EU ministers who threatened to quit her government and offered MPs the chance to delay Brexit and put off the risk of a damaging no-deal scenario.Facing the certainty of a huge rebellion and a wave of resignations, the Prime Minister pledged thatParliament rejects her Brexit deal a second time, there would then be votes on whether to exit the EU without a deal or go ahead with a “short, limited” extension of the Article  negotiation process.: Brexit: Labour to back ‘public vote’ in parliamentThe U-turn has prevented a huge defeat this evening at the hands of pro-EU MPs, who fear the consequences of a no-deal Brexit, but risks driving another wedge between the Prime Minister and Brexiteers, including Mrs May’s DUP allies.Pro-Remain MPs had their fears confirmed yesterday as the government published an impact analysis of a no-deal exit showing British businesses and citizens were unprepared for a chaotic scenario that could be just over a month away.The document, published following pressure from ex-Tory MP Anna Soubry, who resigned from the party last week, showed the economy would be up to  per cent smaller after  years and suggested businesses exporting to the EU faced £ billion of additional costs.With pressure mounting over the looming risk of a damaging no-deal exit, Mrs May told MPs they would have a chance to put that scenario off, but insisted the only way of removing it altogether was by backing her deal.: Brexit: Theresa May delays ‘meaningful vote’ again“I know members across the House are genuinely worried that time is running out, thatthe government doesn’t come back with a further meaningful vote or it loses that vote, Parliament won’t have time to make its voice heard on the next steps,” she said.“I know too that members across the House are deeply concerned by the effect of the current uncertainty on businesses.”Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn accused the PM of “kicking the can down the road”. He confirmed he would table an amendment to today’s motion seeking MPs support for his party’s own customs union deal.The Prime Minister said the Brexit deal would be voted on in the Commons by  March and thatit was rejected again by MPs, there would be a vote the following day on whether to leave the EU without a deal.If the Commons rejects a no-deal scenario, there would then be a vote on  March on whether to ask the EU for a “short, limited extension”.Downing Street declined to say how Conservative MPs would be whipped in the votes or whatof extension would be offeredit came to a motion to extend Article .Mrs May said: “Let me be clear, I do not want to see Article  extended.“Our absolute focus should be on working to get a deal and leaving on  March.“An extension beyond the end of June would mean the UK taking part in the European Parliament elections.“What kind of message would that send to the more than  million people who voted to leave the EU nearly three years ago now “And the House should be clear that a short extension – not beyond the end of June – would almost certainly have to be a one-off.“If we had not taken part in the European Parliament elections, it would be extremely dficult to extend again, so it would create a much sharper clf edge in a few months’ time.”The Prime Minister added: “An extension cannot take no deal off the table. The only way to do that is to revoke Article , which I shall not do, or agree a deal.”Mrs May had faced a wave of resignations by ministers determined to vote for an amendment from Labour MP Yvette Cooper, seeking to tie the government’s hands on an extension to Article .The Prime Minister said her proposals met the timetable set out in Ms Cooper’s amendment. She called on MPs to reject it in votes today, arguing that “tying the government’s hands by seeking to commandeer the order paper would have far-reaching implications for the way in which the United Kingdom is governed, and the balance of powers and responsibilities in our democratic institutions”.In a bid to prevent a rebellion by Tory Brexiteers in two weeks’ time, Mrs May said work would continue on ways to avoid the controversial Irish border backstop from coming into force.“The UK and EU have agreed to consider a joint work stream to develop alternative arrangements to ensure the absence of a hard border in Northern Ireland,” she told MPs. “This work will be done in parallel with the future relationship negotiations and is without prejudice to them.“Our aim is to ensure that, eventhe full future relationship is not in place by the end of the implementation period, the backstop is not needed because we have a set of alternative arrangements ready to go.”The Prime Minister’s critics failed to welcome her U-turn. Mr Corbyn said that “until the Prime Minister is clear what alternative she would put forward in that circumstance, then she is continuing to run down the clock”.He also confirmed that eventhe Prime Minister’s deal was approved by MPs, Labour would seek to make it subject to a “confirmatory referendum”.Veteran Europhile Tory Sir Kenneth Clarke said Mrs May was simply “pushing back the clf edge”.The SNP’s Westminster leader Ian Blackford told the Prime Minister to prepare for a longer extension, saying his party was selecting candidates for the European elections in May.Mr Blackford said Mrs May “could not be trusted” not to dodge another meaningful vote. He urged her to hold votes ruling out no deal now.A cross-party group of MPs will push for a second EU referendum today. An amendment by the Independent Group, supported by the SNP, Liberal Democrats and Plaid Cymru, instructs the Prime Minister to table a motion for debate before  March, setting out the steps necessary for preparing a public vote on whether to leave the EU or remain a member.©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: peers summon jeremy corbyn over exodus of mps from labour party
story: Jeremy Corbyn has been summoned to address Labour peers amid fears members of the group in the House of Lords could join a growing exodus from the party.At a meeting this week following the resignation of seven of the party’s MPs, Labour peers were united in anger at the response to allegations of anti-Semitism by the leadership.Only one peer at Wednesday’s meeting – writer and campaigner Baroness Bryan of Partick, who was appointed to the Lords by Corbyn in June – spoke up in defence of the Labour leader, a source told Scotland on Sunday.At the end of the stormy gathering, peers agreed to ask Corbyn to address them and explain what was being done to respond to the concerns raised by defecting MPs.Explaining her decision to quit, the Liverpool Wavertree MP Luciana Bergersaid the Labour party had become “institutionally anti-Semitic”.Another parliamentarian who quit Labour on Friday, the Dudley North MP Ian Austin, said his Jewish father came to the UK as a child refugee in  while his family remained in Czechoslovakia and were murdered in the Holocaust.“I don’t think I could look at my dad in the eyeI stayed in the Labour Party,” he said.One Labour peer said colleagues fear senior Jewish members of the Labour group in the Lords could quit.The source said senior figures such as former English FA chairman Lord Triesman and the one-time Labour donor Lord Levy were considering their positions.“Only one person defended him [Corbyn]: Baroness Bryan,” the source said.Peers considered sending a deputation to the Labour leader, but a majority insisted he be called to address them. One Jewish peer told colleagues that it was “dficult to go amongst the Jewish community and be a member of the Labour party”.Responding to the wave of resignations, the peers were nearly unanimous in saying they “understand what they’re doing” and “neither condone nor condemn it”, the source said.Labour shadow chancellor John McDonnell admitted that the party needed to be “quicker and fiercer” in responding toincidents of anti-Semitism.In a bid to calm the anger over his handling of the anti-Semitism storm, Corbyn appointed the former minister Lord Falconer to lead a review of the party’s processes.©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: effing heck strike a light made in dagenham s a bit of all right
story: However, be warned ...you are at all offended by swearing edging on the gratuitous and frequent sexual references, yoursquod better get ready to be offended.Looking beyond that, though, it is an incredibly bold decision for the Selkirk Musical Theatre Company to head in this direction, and it seems to be a direction they are revelling in.And itrsquos a barnstorming show. Anyone who has never seen the film starring Sally Hawkins and Bob Hoskins will probably never have heard the songs before, but they instantly feel familiar.Stand-out tunes include the riotous Everybody Out, just before the interval the moving The Letter, sang and acted superbly by Stuart Mitchell as Eddie OrsquoGrady and the rousing Stand Up, by the marvellous Kirsty Cleland playing the lead role of Rita OrsquoGrady, a fictional force of Girl Power representing the women who steadfastly stood up to the Ford factory bosses in the fight for gender equality.With the war for equal pay still very much ongoing, it does seem strange to be watching a musical based more than  years ago which tells the story about a group of women who won their particular battle.The musical is of its time, set in the late s, and as such, portrays a chauvanistic and narcissistic behaviour amongst the men which would in no way be considered OK today, but it is in the characterisation of these strangely behaved people where the Selkirk players shine. Kirsty, as Rita, beautully masters the transition from loving mother to stout campaigner for womenrsquos rights, mostly because there is really no dference between the two.Her colleagues ndash Clare , Sandra , Cass , Connieand the delightfully coarse Beryl, played by Tracy Borthwick, stand by her in her personal struggle after she is ridiculed in a union meeting, and their complaint over their job titles being reclassied as unskilled becomes a moral crusade.Of course, their jobs as sewing machinistsis found to be quite skilled after all and as the women go on strike, the entire factory, which employs more than , men, grinds to a halt.Efforts to get them back to work go as high as secretary of state for employment Barbara Castle, played by an imperious Rachel Inglis, and the man himself, prime minister Harold Wilson. Here, Robin Murray goes to town in this caricature of a politician at the top ... complete with Donald Trump hair, Frank Spencer raincoat and a Groucho Marx everything  ndash great fun.Alongside the main story, there are plot offshoots which are, in turn, quite sweet, incredibly sad and a bit daft.Yvonne Mitchellrsquos Lisa Hopkins heaps up the saccharine in here friendship with Rita, even though she is the we of the factory managing director, superbly played by Jodie Millar.Itrsquos Raymond DrsquoAgrosarsquos turn to shine as Monty when he has some sad news for Rita.And Stuart Mitchell, who is also the company president and choreographer, manages to portray Eddiersquos inability to handle his wersquos new battle for equality, even though it would reek of patheticness today.With a cracking backing cast, a tight orchestra, and seemingly effortless scene changes, Made in Dagenham is a sheer joy.Should you go  Yes.
